[[Fukuoka Sanix Blues|Sanix]] | ru_clubyears = | ru_clubcaps = | ru_clubpoints = | occupation = Early childhood education centre owner{{cite news | url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/business/news/article.cfm?c_id=3&objectid=10805104 | title=Childcare a paying proposition | date=11 May 2012 | work=New Zealand Herald | accessdate=24 July 2014 | first=Nick | last=Smith }} | family = | spouse = | children = | relatives = | school = [[Palmerston North Boys' High School]] | university = }} '''Mark Clayton Finlay''' (born 10 May 1963) is a former New Zealand [[rugby union]] player. He was educated at [[Palmerston North Boys' High School]], where he was a member of the 1st XV between 1979 and 1981. A [[Rugby union positions#Full-back|fullback]], Finlay represented [[Manawatu Rugby Union|Manawatu]] and [[North Harbour Rugby Union|North Harbour]] at a provincial level, and was a member of the New Zealand national side, the [[All Blacks]], in 1984. He played two matches for the All Blacks where he scored a total of 18 points (2 tries, 5 conversions), but made no test appearances.{{Cite book|title = The Encyclopedia Of New Zealand Rugby|last = Chester|first = Rod|publisher = Moa Publications|year = 1987|isbn = 0-908570-16-3|location = Auckland, New Zealand|pages = 61|last2 = McMillan|first2 = Neville|last3 = Palenski|first3 = Ron}}{{cite web| url = http://stats.allblacks.com/asp/Profile.asp?ABID=272 |title = Mark Finlay | last = Knight | first = Lindsay | publisher = New Zealand Rugby Union | accessdate = 24 July 2014}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Portal|Rugby union}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Finlay, Mark}} [[Category:1963 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Rugby union players from Palmerston North]] [[Category:People educated at Palmerston North Boys' High School]] [[Category:New Zealand rugby union players]] [[Category:New Zealand international rugby union players]] [[Category:Manawatu rugby union players]] [[Category:North Harbour rugby union players]] [[Category:Rugby union fullbacks]] [[Category:New Zealand expatriate rugby union players]] [[Category:Expatriate rugby union players in Italy]] [[Category:New Zealand expatriates in Italy]] [[Category:New Zealand expatriates in Japan]] [[Category:Expatriate rugby union players in Japan]] [[Category:New Zealand businesspeople]] {{NewZealand-rugbyunion-bio-stub}}

revision.comment: /* Personal life */clean up, [[WP:AWB/T|typo(s) fixed]]: businese → businesse, neices → nieces (2) using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
[[Image:Martin Chilcott.jpg|thumb|right|Martin Chilcott]] '''Martin Chilcott''' (born 12 December 1965) is a British entrepreneur specializing in environment and education, best known as the founder and CEO of [[2degrees Network|2degrees]], the world’s largest community for [[sustainable business]].
His first successful business venture was CTSS, a specialist technology marketing company, with colleague and friend [[James Tarin]]. In 1995, he established Clarity Communications, followed by various companies that included Meltwater Ventures, a green business incubation service.
==Early life==
Chilcott was born in [[Aldershot]], [[Hampshire]], the son of Rosemary and Lt-Col Michael John-Patrick Chilcott. Chilcott was educated at [[St Joseph's College, Ipswich|St Josephs College, Ipswich]] before going on to study History at [[Clare College, Cambridge]].
==Career==
In 1989, Chilcott started CTSS, a specialist technology marketing consultancy, with his current business partner, James Tarin. Their main client for 5 years was a small start-up business called The [[Carphone Warehouse]], which would grow into Europe’s largest independent mobile phone retailer.<ref>http://www.carphonewarehouse.com/store-locator</ref> As a result of its success, Chilcott’s business moved to London and in 1995 founded Clarity IBD Ltd, an [[Electronic business|e-business]] consultancy that would work with [[Abbey National]] and [[National Rail]] to create online content. This was later acquired by [[Proxicom]], another [[Electronic business|e-business]] consultancy.<ref>http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m0EIN/is_2000_April_20/ai_61592992/</ref> After various further business ventures Chilcott co-founded Place Group, an educational consultancy company, in 2005.<ref>http://www.place-group.com/</ref> He would spend the next few years working alongside local authorities and national government programs until, by 2008, they were the market leader in delivering school-academy transitions in the UK.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.place-group.com/news062.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-07-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120328022013/http://www.place-group.com/news062.html |archivedate=2012-03-28 |df= }}</ref>
A year after the founding of Place Group, Chilcott started a business incubator called Meltwater Ventures that specialized in environmental programs and resource scarcity. Meltwater Ventures would eventually generate the idea for 2degrees.
==2degrees==
By 2006, Chilcott had been drawn to sustainability and carbon reduction, having seen the opportunity build on a valuable business niche there. He, along with James Tarin, recognized that many business were attempting to solve similar sustainability problems independent of each other, but that and that there was no online community which could be used to connect them and collectively solve problems. This thinking led to the founding of the [[2degrees Network|2degrees Community]] in 2008 and, by 2011, it was the world largest Community for Sustainable Business and had offices in the UK and US.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.justmeans.com/press-releases/The-Worlds-largest-sustainability-network-defines-key-competencies-to-thrive-through-the-4th-economic-revolution/7402.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-07-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110714002553/http://www.justmeans.com/press-releases/The-Worlds-largest-sustainability-network-defines-key-competencies-to-thrive-through-the-4th-economic-revolution/7402.html |archivedate=2011-07-14 |df= }}</ref>
==Personal life==
Martin Chilcott currently lives in [[Oxford]] and currently spends his time between his family, his business, and maintaining his Dutch barge.
He is also a trustee of [[Oxford business x]], a youth enterprise scheme based at the [[Said Business School]] in Oxford.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.charitiesdirect.com/charities/oxford-business-x-1139847.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-07-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110927180813/http://www.charitiesdirect.com/charities/oxford-business-x-1139847.html |archivedate=2011-09-27 |df= }}</ref>
In 2011, he sat on the panel of judges for [[The Guardian]]'s Sustainable Business Awards 2011.<ref>https://www.theguardian.com/sustainable-business/judges-martin-chilcott</ref>
Martin is the fourth child of five. He has 11 nephews and nieces as well as one great niece (Ottilie Sowerby) - His favourite nephews are Berty and Harry Chilcott.
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == * New Business interview with Martin Chilcott [http://www.newbusiness.co.uk/articles/planning-advice/why-having-business-experience-can-be-invaluable] * 2degrees Network [http://www.2degreesnetwork.com]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Chilcott, Martin}} [[Category:British businesspeople]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Articles created via the Article Wizard]] [[Category:1965 births]] [[Category:People educated at St Joseph's College, Ipswich]]

revision.text:
{{pp|small=yes}} {{More citations needed|date=November 2014}} {{Infobox company | name = Orion Pictures Corporation | logo = [[Image:Orion Pictures logo.png|Orion Pictures 1984 logo|250px]] | caption = The company’s 1984 logo with a 2018 modification from the trailer of ''[[Every Day (2018 film)|Every Day]]'' | fate = | foundation = 1978 | defunct = | predecessor = [[Filmways]] | type = [[Subsidiary]] | location = [[Los Angeles, California, United States]] | area_served = Worldwide | founders = {{ubl|[[Arthur B. Krim]]|[[Eric Pleskow]]|[[Mike Medavoy]]|William Bernstein|[[Robert Benjamin]]}} | key_people = {{ubl|John Hegeman (president)|John Bryan|(president, MGM Domestic TV Distribution)}} | industry = [[Film]] | products = [[Motion picture]]s | parent = {{ubl|[[Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer]]|([[MGM Holdings|MGM Holdings, Inc.]])|(1997-present)|[[Metromedia]] (1988-1997)}} | brands = [[Orion Classics]] | subsid = Orion Pictures Distribution Corporation
[[Orion Television|Orion TV Productions, Inc.]] }} '''Orion Pictures Corporation''' is an American [[List of film production companies|motion picture producer]] and [[Film distributor|distributor]] that produced and released films from 1978 until 1999 and was also involved in television production and syndication throughout the 1980s until the early 1990s. It was formed in 1978 as a [[joint venture]] between [[Warner Bros.]] and three former top-level executives of [[United Artists]]. Although it was never a large motion picture producer, Orion achieved a comparatively high reputation for [[Hollywood]] quality.{{cite news|title= Whither Orion? : The Last of the Mini-Major Studios Finds Itself at a Crossroads|publisher= [[The Los Angeles Times]]|date=1990-07-19|url= http://articles.latimes.com/1990-07-19/entertainment/ca-363_1_studio-executives|accessdate=2010-12-28|first=Nina J.|last=Easton}} [[Woody Allen]], [[James Cameron]], [[Jonathan Demme]], [[Oliver Stone]], and several other prominent directors worked with Orion during its most successful years from 1978 to 1992. Of the films distributed by Orion, four won [[Academy Award]]s for [[Academy Award for Best Picture|Best Picture]]: ''[[Amadeus (film)|Amadeus]]'' (1984), ''[[Platoon (film)|Platoon]]'' (1986), ''[[Dances with Wolves]]'' (1990), and ''[[The Silence of the Lambs (film)|The Silence of the Lambs]]'' (1991). Two other Orion films, ''[[Hannah and Her Sisters]]'' (1986) and ''[[Mississippi Burning]]'' (1988), were nominated for that same category. In 2013, [[Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer]] revived the Orion name for television; a year later, Orion Pictures was relaunched by the studio. ==History== ===Beginnings: 1978–1981=== In January 1978, three executives of [[Transamerica Corporation|Transamerica]] (TA)-owned studio [[United Artists]] (UA) – [[Arthur B. Krim]] (chairman), [[Eric Pleskow]] (president and chief executive officer), and [[Robert S. Benjamin]] (chairman of the finance committee) - quit their jobs. Krim and Benjamin had headed UA since 1951, and subsequently turned around the then-flailing studio with a number of critical and commercial successes. Change had begun once Transamerica purchased UA in 1967, and within a decade a rift formed between Krim and TA chairman Jack Beckett regarding the studio's operations. Krim suggested spinning off United Artists into a separate company, which was rejected by Beckett.Medavoy and Young, pp. 83-90 The last straw came for Pleskow when he refused to collect and deliver the medical records of UA department heads to Transamerica's offices in San Francisco for the sake of confidentiality. The tensions only worsened when ''Fortune'' magazine reported an article on the clash between UA and TA, in which Beckett had stated that if the executives disliked the parent company's treatment of them, they should resign. Krim, Benjamin, and Pleskow quit United Artists on January 13, 1978, followed by the exits of senior vice presidents William Bernstein and [[Mike Medavoy]] three days later. The week following the resignations, according to the website ''Reference for Business'', "63 important Hollywood figures took out an advertisement in a trade paper warning UA that it had made a fatal mistake in letting the five men leave. The 'fatal mistake' came true following the box office disaster of ''[[Heaven's Gate (film)|Heaven's Gate]]''"[http://www.referenceforbusiness.com/history2/48/ORION-PICTURES-CORPORATION.html "Orion Pictures Corporation."] ''Reference for Business'' which led to Transamerica selling UA to [[Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer]].{{cite news |last1=Champlin |first1=Charles |title=That's a Wrap: End of MGM/UA That Was |url=http://articles.latimes.com/1990-11-20/entertainment/ca-5110_1_mgm-lot |accessdate=2013-08-16 |work=Los Angeles Times |date=November 20, 1990}} In February 1978, the five men forged a deal with [[Warner Bros.]] The executives formed Orion Pictures Company, named after [[Orion (constellation)|the constellation]], which they claimed had five main stars (it actually has seven/eight). The new company intended only to finance projects, giving the filmmakers complete creative autonomy; this ideal was implemented with great success at United Artists. Orion held a $100 million line of credit, and its films would be distributed by the [[Warner Bros.]] studio. Orion, however, was contractually given free rein over distribution and advertising, as well as the number and type of films the executives chose to invest in.Medavoy and Young, pp. 95-97 In late March 1978, Orion signed its first contract; a two-picture deal with [[John Travolta]]'s production company. Contracts with actress and director [[Barbra Streisand]]; actors [[James Caan (actor)|James Caan]], [[Jane Fonda]], [[Peter Sellers]], [[Jon Voight]], and [[Burt Reynolds]]; directors [[Francis Ford Coppola]] and [[Blake Edwards]]; writer/director [[John Milius]]; singer [[Peter Frampton]]; and producer [[Ray Stark]] soon materialized.Associated Press. [https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=HbssAAAAIBAJ&sjid=LxMEAAAAIBAJ&pg=4846,4749317&dq=orion+pictures&hl=en "Top Stars Join Orion Pictures"] ''Wilmington Morning Star'' (November 22, 1978; page 10-A). Retrieved November 2, 2011. Orion also developed a co-financing and distribution deal with [[EMI Films]]. In its first year, Orion had 15 films into productions plus were in production, and had a dozen more actors, directors and producers line up to sign up with Orion. In 1979, Benjamin died. Orion's first film, ''[[A Little Romance]]'',Medavoy and Young, p. 104 was released in April that year. That year, Orion released [[Blake Edwards]]' ''[[10 (film)|10]]'', which became a big critical and commercial success; the first for Edwards in over a decade (aside from installments of ''[[The Pink Panther (film series)|The Pink Panther]]'' franchise). Other films released in that period included ''[[Caddyshack]]''; ''[[The Great Santini]]'', a critically praised but underpromoted adaptation of a [[Pat Conroy]] novel; and ''[[Promises in the Dark (film)|Promises in the Dark]]''. Out of the 23 films Orion released between April 1979 and December 1981, only a third of them made a profit.Medavoy and Young, p. 115 Orion executives were conflicted over financing big-budgeted films and passed on ''[[Raiders of the Lost Ark]]'' for that reason.Medavoy and Young, p. 114-115 ===Acquisition of Filmways: 1981–1983=== By early 1982, Orion had severed its distribution ties with Warner. As part of the deal, the rights to Orion's films made up to that point were sold to Warner. Orion was now looking to have its own distribution network by acquiring another company with such capabilities. The four partners looked into [[Monogram Pictures|Allied Artists]] and [[Embassy Pictures]]Medavoy and Young, p. 122 before settling on [[Filmways]].{{cite book|last=Tzioumakis|first=Yannis|title=AMERICAN INDEPENDENT CINEMA|year=2006|publisher=Edinburgh University Press|location=Edinburgh|pages=228–229}} Orion subsequently purchased Filmways and reorganized the flailing company. New employees were hired and all of Filmways' non-entertainment assets ([[Grosset & Dunlap]] and [[Broadcast Electronics]]) were sold off. On August 31, 1982, Filmways was renamed as Orion Pictures Corporation. Another result of the merger was that Orion entered television production. Orion's biggest TV hit was ''[[Cagney & Lacey]]'', which lasted seven seasons on CBS. In 1983, Orion Pictures introduced art-house division [[Orion Classics]] with executives who had previously run [[United Artists|United Artists Classics]]. ===Problems arise: 1984–1986=== According to ''Reference for Business'': "Of the first 18 movies the company had released as Orion Pictures Corporation, ten had been profitable, five had broken even, and three had losses of less than $2 million." One such film, [[Francis Ford Coppola]]'s ''[[The Cotton Club (film)|The Cotton Club]]'', was mired in legal troubles and Orion lost $3 million of its investment. '"We've had some singles and doubles [but haven't] had any home runs," lamented Krim. In September 1984, Orion distributed ''[[Amadeus (film)|Amadeus]]'', which garnered many accolades, winning eight [[Academy Awards]], including [[Academy Award for Best Picture|Best Picture]]. For Orion, 1985 was a dismal year. All but two films, ''[[Desperately Seeking Susan]]'' and ''[[Code of Silence (film)|Code of Silence]]'', made less than $10 million in the United States box office, including an unsuccessful attempt at a [[James Bond]]-type franchise, ''[[Remo Williams: The Adventure Begins]]''. Orion's haphazard distribution channels and unsuccessful advertising campaigns made it impossible to achieve a hit. Another factor was that Orion was about to venture into the video business and stopped selling off home use rights to its films. Furthermore, production of the [[Rodney Dangerfield]] comedy ''[[Back to School]]'' was put on hold when a co-producer died, taking the film off of its Christmas 1985 release slate.Kornbluth, Jesse (April 6, 1987). ''The Little Studio that Could'' (pp. 48-54). ''[[New York Magazine]]''. In January 1986, [[Mario Kassar]] and [[Andrew Vajna]], producers of the ''[[Rambo (film series)|Rambo]]'' films (the first film, ''[[First Blood (film)|First Blood]]'', was distributed by Orion) attempted to buy $55 million worth of the studio's stock through the duo's company, [[Carolco Pictures|Anabasis]]. Had they succeeded, Kassar and Vajna would have controlled the board and laid off every executive save for Krim. Warburg Pincus subsequently limited its 20% stake in Orion to 5%; the remaining stocks were acquired by [[Viacom (original)|Viacom International]]. Viacom hoped to use Orion's product for its pay-TV channel [[Showtime (TV network)|Showtime]].Medavoy and Young, p. 181. Orion expanded into home video distribution with the formation of Orion Home Entertainment Corporation. ===Metromedia era: 1986–1991=== On May 22, 1986, [[Metromedia]], a television and communications company controlled by billionaire (and a friend of Krim's) [[John Kluge]], which had just divested of its television station group to [[Rupert Murdoch]]'s [[News Corporation]] (which would form what is now the [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox network]]), purchased a 6.5% stake in Orion. Kluge's investment in the company came at the right time- ''Back to School'' was a success and ultimately earned $90 million at the box office. By March 1987, the studio's fortunes increased dramatically with a succession of critical and commercial hits, including ''[[Platoon (film)|Platoon]]'' (which ultimately won a Best Picture Oscar), Woody Allen's ''[[Hannah and Her Sisters]]'', and the sports film ''[[Hoosiers (film)|Hoosiers]]''. Orion's 1986 offerings totaled 18 Academy Award nominations, more than any other studio. In 1987, Orion achieved further success with ''[[RoboCop]]'', and ''[[No Way Out (1987 film)|No Way Out]]''. By this time, Orion's television division had expanded into the lucrative syndicated game show market under the name ''Century Towers Productions'', in reference to Orion's street address at the time. It produced revivals of format inherited from [[Heatter-Quigley Productions]] after the Filmways merger (as Filmways had previously acquired HQ in the late 1960s); this included ''[[Hollywood Squares|The New Hollywood Squares]]'', which ran from 1986 to 1989, and a revival of ''[[High Rollers]]'' which aired in the 1987-88 season. In January 1987, Kluge faced big competition with the arrival of [[Sumner Redstone]]. His theater chain, [[National Amusements]], purchased 6.42 percent of the company's stock. National Amusements later acquired Viacom, increasing their Orion stake at 21%, then 26%. Soon Kluge started buying more Orion stock, leading to him and Redstone battling it out to take over the company.{{cite news|title= COMPANY NEWS; Orion Pictures Stake Increased|work= The New York Times|date=1987-12-17|url= https://www.nytimes.com/1987/12/17/business/company-news-orion-pictures-stake-increased.html?scp=1&sq=Orion%20Pictures&st=cse|accessdate=2010-08-08}}{{cite news|title= A 6.5% Stake In Orion Pictures|work= The New York Times|date=1986-06-03|url= https://www.nytimes.com/1986/06/03/business/a-6.5-stake-in-orion-pictures.html?scp=7&sq=Orion%20Pictures&st=cse|accessdate=2010-08-08}} Kluge ultimately succeeded when Metromedia took over approximately 67% of Orion on May 20, 1988, effectively giving him control of the studio. One analyst commented on the takeover to the ''Wall Street Journal'': "This amount is probably so small to Kluge it doesn't matter. He probably burns that up in a weekend." In 1989, Orion suffered from a disastrous slate of films, placing themselves dead last among the major Hollywood studios in terms of box office revenue. Among its biggest flops that year were ''[[Great Balls of Fire! (film)|Great Balls of Fire!]]'', the biography of [[Jerry Lee Lewis]] starring [[Dennis Quaid]] and [[Winona Ryder]]; ''[[She-Devil (film)|She-Devil]]'', a dark comedy starring [[Meryl Streep]] and [[Roseanne Barr]]; and [[Miloš Forman]]'s adaptation of ''[[Les Liaisons dangereuses]]'', ''[[Valmont (film)|Valmont]]'', which competed with ''[[Dangerous Liaisons]]'', also based on the same source material. Test screenings of the [["Weird Al" Yankovic]] comedy ''[[UHF (film)|UHF]]'' were so strong that Orion had high expectations for it. It flopped at first, but it has since attained a strong cult following.{{cite AV media notes | title = Permanent Record: Al in the Box | titlelink = | others = "Weird Al" Yankovic | year = 1994 | url = http://dmdb.org/al/booklet.html | first = Barret | last = Hansen | authorlink = Dr. Demento | type = liner | publisher = Scotti Brothers Records | location = [[California]], [[United States|USA]] }} In February 1990, Orion signed a deal with [[Columbia Pictures|Columbia Pictures Entertainment]] in which the much larger studio would pay Orion $175 million to distribute Orion's movies and television programs overseas. Orion had previously licensed its films to individual distributors territory by territory. That same month, Mike Medavoy left Orion and became head of [[Tri-Star Pictures]].Medavoy and Young, p. 201 1990 was just as dismal for Orion as the year prior, with such failures as ''[[The Hot Spot]]'' and ''[[State of Grace (1990 film)|State of Grace]]''. The only bright spot that year was [[Kevin Costner]]'s western epic ''[[Dances with Wolves]]''. It won seven Academy Awards, including Best Picture,{{cite news|title= BUSINESS PEOPLE; Chief at Orion Pictures Is Joining Paramount|work= The New York Times|date=1992-02-21|url= https://www.nytimes.com/1992/02/21/business/business-people-chief-at-orion-pictures-is-joining-paramount.html?scp=4&sq=Orion%20Pictures&st=cse|accessdate=2010-08-08 | first=Anthony | last=Ramirez}} and grossed $400 million worldwide. A few months later, Orion garnered another winner with ''[[The Silence of the Lambs (film)|The Silence of the Lambs]]'', but these two films could not make up for years of losses. Only Kluge's continued infusions of cash were enough to keep the company afloat, but soon he had enough. ===Bankruptcy: 1991–1995=== After failing to sell Orion to businessman (and former 20th Century Fox owner) [[Marvin Davis]] ([[Sony]], which had recently purchased [[Columbia Pictures]] was also interested{{cite news|title= COMPANY NEWS; Orion Pictures' Stock Increases|work= The New York Times|date=1991-02-09|url= https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/09/business/company-news-orion-pictures-stock-increases.html?scp=5&sq=Orion%20Pictures&st=cse|accessdate=2010-08-08}}), Kluge took drastic steps. First, Orion shut down production. Second, Kluge ordered the sale of several projects, such as ''[[The Addams Family (1991 film)|The Addams Family]]'' (which went to [[Paramount Pictures|Paramount]], though the international rights to the film were retained by Orion), in order to accumulate much-needed cash. Finally, in the spring of 1991, Kluge's people took over the company, leading to the departure of Arthur Krim.Medavoy and Young, pp. 202-203. Orion's financial problems were so severe, that at the 63rd Annual Academy Awards in March 1991, host [[Billy Crystal]] made reference to the studio's debt in his opening monologue, joking that "''[[Reversal of Fortune]]'' [is] about a woman in a coma, ''[[Awakenings (film)|Awakenings]]'' [is] about a man in a coma; and ''Dances with Wolves'' [was] released by Orion, a studio in a coma."[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=x0lWrZL0EHE Billy Crystal Oscars Opening -- 1991 Academy Awards.] [[The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences]]-YouTube Channel. Retrieved on June 11, 2013. It was during this time that [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] stepped in to co-finance and assume production over many of Orion TV's shows it had in production, such as ''[[American Detective]]'' and ''[[Equal Justice (TV series)|Equal Justice]]''. On November 25, 1991, Orion sold its ''[[Hollywood Squares]]'' format rights to [[King World Productions]] after Orion closed down its television division.{{cite journal|date=1991-11-25|title=King Gets the Square |journal=Broadcasting|page=26}} On December 11, 1991, Orion filed for [[Chapter 11 bankruptcy]] protection. In December 1991, Orion was in talks with [[New Line Cinema]], a successful independent film company, to acquire the bankrupt studio. By the following April, Orion and New Line Cinema cancelled their plans on the issue of price. [[Republic Pictures]] and the then-new [[Savoy Pictures]] also attempted to buy Orion, but no deal materialized.{{cite news|title= THE MEDIA BUSINESS; New Line Breaks Off Talks On Buying Orion Pictures|work= The New York Times|date=1992-04-22|url= https://www.nytimes.com/1992/04/22/business/the-media-business-new-line-breaks-off-talks-on-buying-orion-pictures.html?scp=6&sq=Orion%20Pictures&st=cse|accessdate=2010-08-08 | first=Richard W. | last=Stevenson}}{{cite news|title= COMPANY NEWS; 2d Company Makes Bid for Orion Pictures|work= The New York Times|date=1992-04-10|url= https://www.nytimes.com/1992/04/10/business/company-news-2d-company-makes-bid-for-orion-pictures.html?scp=2&sq=Orion%20Pictures&st=cse|accessdate=2010-08-08}} At the Academy Awards ceremony, broadcast on March 30, 1992, Crystal yet made another reference to Orion, this time about its demise: {{cquote|Take a great studio like Orion: a few years ago Orion released ''Platoon'', it wins Best Picture. ''Amadeus'', Best Picture. Last year, they released ''Dances with Wolves'' wins Best Picture. This year ''The Silence of the Lambs'' is nominated for Best Picture. And they can't afford to have another hit! But there is good news and bad news. The good news is that Orion was just purchased, and the bad news is it was bought by the House of Representatives.[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UCAi1744Sa0 Billy Crystal Oscars Opening -- 1992 Academy Awards.] [[The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences]]-YouTube Channel. Retrieved on June 11, 2013.}} ''The Silence of the Lambs'' swept all five major Academy Awards; however, a majority of key executives, as well as the talent they had deals with, had left the studio. Hollywood observers had doubts that Orion would be resurrected to its former glory.{{cite news|title= Orion Pictures' Losses Widen|work= The New York Times|date=1992-04-08|url= https://www.nytimes.com/1992/04/08/business/orion-pictures-losses-widen.html?scp=8&sq=Orion%20Pictures&st=cse|accessdate=2010-08-08}} On November 5, 1992, Orion reemerged from bankruptcy. Its reorganization plan would allow for Orion to continue producing and releasing films, but financing for the features would be provided by outside sources, with the studio purchasing the distribution rights to them after their completion.{{Cite news|url=https://variety.com/1992/biz/news/orion-emerges-from-chapter-11-100780/|title=Orion emerges from Chapter 11|last=Brennan|first=Paul Noglows, Judy|date=1992-11-06|work=Variety|access-date=2017-05-25|language=en-US}}{{cite web|url=http://yahoo.brand.edgar-online.com/displayfilinginfo.aspx?FilingID=343274-5759-53456&type=sect&tabindex=2|title=EDGAR Pro|website=yahoo.brand.edgar-online.com|access-date=2017-05-25}} Orion's bankruptcy also delayed the release of many films the studio had produced or acquired, among them: ''[[Love Field (film)|Love Field]]'' (1992), ''[[RoboCop 3]]'' (1993), ''[[The Dark Half (film)|The Dark Half]]'' (1993), ''[[Blue Sky (film)|Blue Sky]]'' (1994), ''[[Car 54, Where Are You? (film)|Car 54, Where Are You?]]'' (1994), ''[[Clifford (film)|Clifford]]'' (1994), ''[[The Favor]]'' (1994), and ''[[There Goes My Baby (film)|There Goes My Baby]]'' (1994). Orion started releasing these films after their reorganization. ''Blue Sky'' won star [[Jessica Lange]] an Academy Award for Best Actress in 1995. ===Metromedia International Group=== In November 1995, Orion and three other companies controlled by Kluge were merged to form the Metromedia International Group.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/02/business/the-media-business-actava-group-seals-stock-swap.html|title=THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Actava Group Seals Stock Swap|last=Bloomberg Business News|first=|date=1995-11-02|work=|newspaper=The New York Times|issn=0362-4331|access-date=2016-11-01|via=}} Few of the films released during the four years after [[Chapter 11, Title 11, United States Code|bankruptcy protection]] were successful either critically or commercially. In 1996, Metromedia acquired production company [[Motion Picture Corporation of America]], and installed its heads, Brad Krevoy and Steve Stabler, as co-presidents of Orion. Both received a six picture put picture distribution deal as a part of their contracts.{{cite news|last1=Horn|first1=John|title=Coming soon, to very few theaters|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2005/feb/21/entertainment/et-mgm21|accessdate=June 10, 2016|work=Los Angeles Times|date=February 21, 2005}} In the years ahead, Orion produced very few films, and primarily released films from other producers, including [[Artisan Entertainment|LIVE Entertainment]]. [[Orion Classics]], minus its founders (who had moved to [[Sony Pictures|Sony Pictures Entertainment]] and founded [[Sony Pictures Classics]]), continued to acquire popular [[art-house]] films, such as ''[[Boxing Helena]]'' (1993), before Metromedia merged the subsidiary with [[The Samuel Goldwyn Company|Samuel Goldwyn Entertainment]] in 1996. ===Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer subsidiary=== In July 1997, Metromedia shareholders approved the sale of Orion (as well as Samuel Goldwyn Entertainment and [[Motion Picture Corporation of America]]) to [[Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer]]. This led to the withdrawal of 85 employees, including Krevoy and Stabler, while 111 other employees were to be laid off within nine months, leaving 25 of them to work at MGM. Orion also brought with it, a two thousand film library, ten completed movies and five direct-to-video features for future release{{cite news | last = Weiner | first = Rex | date = July 11, 1997 | title = MGM ends Orion orbit | url = https://variety.com/1997/film/news/mgm-ends-orion-orbit-1116676950/ | newspaper= Variety | location = | access-date = Jun 10, 2016 }} and the Krevoy and Stabler movie put picture distribution deal. Krevoy and Stabler retained the right to the Motion Picture Corporation of America name and their three top movies. Metromedia retained Goldwyn Entertainment's Landmark Theatre Group. ''[[One Man's Hero]]'' (1999) was the last film released by Orion for 15 years. MGM kept Orion intact as a corporation thus to avoid its Warner Bros. video distribution agreement and began distributing Orion Pictures films under the Orion Home Video label. MGM acquired the 2/3 of pre-1996 [[PolyGram Filmed Entertainment]] library from [[Seagram]] in 1999 for $250 million, increasing their library holdings to 4,000. The PolyGram libraries were purchased by its Orion Pictures subsidiary so as to avoid its 1990 video distribution agreement with Warner.{{cite news|last=Eller|first=Claudia |title=MGM Agrees to Acquire PolyGram Movie Library|date=23 October 1998|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]] |url=http://articles.latimes.com/1998/oct/23/business/fi-35357 |accessdate=29 March 2015}} In March 1999, MGM bought out its distribution contract with Warner Bros. for $225 million, effectively ending the distribution problem.{{Cite web|url=https://www.thefreelibrary.com/MGM+REGAINS+VIDEO+RIGHTS%253B+$225+MILLION+DEAL+TO+HELP+SELL+DVDS.-a083605917|title=MGM REGAINS VIDEO RIGHTS; $225 MILLION DEAL TO HELP SELL DVDS. - Free Online Library|website=www.thefreelibrary.com|access-date=2018-04-10}} In 2013, MGM revived the Orion Television brand (after Orion's original TV unit was shut down during its bankruptcy era in the early 1990s) as Orion TV Productions with a new syndicated series, ''[[Lauren Lake's Paternity Court|Paternity Court]]''.{{cite news|last1=Saval|first1=Malina|title=MGM TV Rides High With ‘Vikings’ and ‘Fargo’|url=https://variety.com/2014/tv/festivals/mgm-tv-rides-high-with-vikings-and-fargo-1201152961/|accessdate=October 28, 2015|work=Variety|issue=April 1, 2014|publisher=Penske Business Media, LLC|date=April 4, 2014}} The Orion Pictures name, also as Orion Releasing, was extended in fourth quarter 2014 for smaller multi-platform video on demand and limited theatrical distribution. Its name was first seen again on September 10, 2014 in front of the trailer for ''[[The Town That Dreaded Sundown (2014 film)|The Town That Dreaded Sundown]]'' that was released in October. The label's first release was the Brazilian film ''Vestido pra Casar''.{{cite news|last1=Torrelio|first1=Sebastian|title=Orion Pictures Label Returns for First Time in 15 Years|url=https://variety.com/2014/film/news/orion-pictures-label-returns-for-first-time-in-15-years-1201304184/|accessdate=March 10, 2017|work=Variety|date=September 11, 2014}} In September 2015, [[Entertainment One Films]] relaunched the [[Momentum Pictures]] banner with an announced deal with Orion Pictures to co-acquire and co-distribute films in the United States and Canada, and selected foreign markets, such as the [[United Kingdom]] (Momentum's country of origin). The initial films under the deal were ''[[The Wannabe]]'', ''[[Fort Tilden (film)|Fort Tilden]]'' and ''[[Balls Out (2014 film)|Balls Out]]''.{{Cite news|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/tiff-eone-relaunches-momentum-pictures-821351|title=TIFF: eOne Relaunches Momentum Pictures Label With Orion Releasing Deal|newspaper=The Hollywood Reporter|access-date=2016-11-01}} Other films released by Orion Pictures and [[Momentum Pictures]] include ''[[Pocket Listing (film)|Pocket Listing]]'' and ''[[Diablo (2015 film)|Diablo]]''.{{cite web | last=Kay | first=Jeremy | url=http://www.screendaily.com/news/production/shoot-wraps-on-pocket-listing/5065176.article | title=Shoot wraps on Pocket Listing | website=ScreenDaily | date=January 8, 2014 | accessdate=February 9, 2017}}{{cite web | last=Busch | first=Anita | title=Orion Pictures Picks up ‘Pocket Listing’ For Limited Theatrical Release | url=http://deadline.com/2016/11/pocket-listing-theatrical-release-2016-rob-lowe-burt-reynolds-1201848696/ | website=Deadline | date=November 4, 2016 | accessdate=February 9, 2017}}{{cite news|last1=Vlessing|first1=Ethan|title=Scott Eastwood's 'Diablo' Nabbed by Orion Releasing, Momentum|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/scott-eastwoods-diablo-nabbed-by-840589|accessdate=18 March 2016|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|date=16 November 2015}} Starting in September 2016 with ''[[Burn Country]]'', Orion Pictures and [[Samuel Goldwyn Films]] paired in acquiring several films.{{cite news|last=Hipes |first=Patrick |url=http://deadline.com/2016/09/burn-country-dominic-rains-release-date-samuel-goldwyn-orion-pictures-1201816023/ |title=Ian Olds’ ‘Burn Country’ Acquired By Samuel Goldwyn & Orion |publisher=Deadline |date=2016-09-09 |accessdate=April 26, 2017}}{{cite web|last=Hipes |first=Patrick |url=http://deadline.com/2016/12/past-life-israel-movie-orion-samuel-goldwyn-1201871935/ |title=Israeli Thriller ‘Past Life’ Lands At Orion & Samuel Goldwyn |website=Deadline |date=2016-12-15 |accessdate=April 26, 2017}}{{cite web|last=Hipes |first=Patrick |url=http://deadline.com/2016/12/youth-in-oregon-release-date-frank-langella-orion-samuel-goldwyn-1201873616/ |title=‘Youth In Oregon’: Release Date Set For Frank Langella Movie After Deal |website=Deadline |date=2016-12-19 |accessdate=April 26, 2017}}{{cite web|author=Amanda N'Duka |url=http://deadline.com/2017/03/the-orchard-super-dark-times-orion-pictures-samuel-goldwyn-films-tracktown-1202038668/ |title=The Orchard Lands ’Super Dark Times’; Orion, Samuel Goldwyn Nab ‘Tracktown’ |website=Deadline |date=2017-03-07 |accessdate=April 26, 2017}} In 2017, Orion TV added another court series, ''Couples Court'', to its syndicated line up. The show is presided over by a husband wife team and deals with marital issues primarily cheating.{{cite news|last1=Desk|first1=TV News|title=Orion Television's COUPLES COURT Coming to National Syndication This Fall|url=http://www.broadwayworld.com/bwwtv/article/Orion-Televisions-COUPLES-COURT-Coming-to-National-Syndication-This-Fall-20170113#|accessdate=March 10, 2017|website=Broadway World|publisher=Wisdom Digital Media|date=January 13, 2017|language=en}} On September 6, 2017, MGM officially revitalized the Orion Pictures brand as a standalone, US theatrical marketing and distribution arm with the hiring of John Hegeman, who had come from [[Blumhouse Productions|Blumhouse Tilt]] (distributor of Orion's ''[[The Town That Dreaded Sundown (2014 film)|The Town That Dreaded Sundown]]'' and ''[[The Belko Experiment]]'') and incidentally got his start working at the old Orion in the 1980s. Hegeman will serve as president of the expanded label and report to [[Jonathan Glickman]], president of MGM's motion picture group. Under his leadership, the "new" Orion will produce, market and distribute four to six modestly budgeted films a year across genres and platforms, both wide and limited releases for targeted audiences, and its first release, the young adult romance drama ''[[Every Day (2018 film)|Every Day]]'', was released in February 23, 2018.{{cite web|author=Dave McNary |url=https://variety.com/2017/film/news/mgm-re-launching-orion-pictures-distributor-1202548889/ |title=MGM Relaunching Orion Pictures as Distributor |work=Variety |date=2017-09-06 |accessdate=2018-01-03}}{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/mgm-relaunches-orion-pictures-under-john-hegeman-1035761 |title=MGM Relaunches Orion Pictures Under John Hegeman |work=The Hollywood Reporter |date= |accessdate=2018-01-03}}{{cite web|last=Busch |first=Anita |url=http://deadline.com/2017/09/orion-pictures-relaunched-mgm-john-hegeman-president-1202162614/ |title=Orion Label Relaunched By MGM As Stand-Alone; John Hegeman President |website=Deadline |date=2017-09-06 |accessdate=2018-01-03}}{{cite web|author=Nick Romano |url=http://ew.com/movies/2017/12/06/angourie-rice-every-day-first-look-photos/ |title=Angourie Rice stars in Every Day movie first-look photos |website=EW.com |date=2017-12-06 |accessdate=2018-01-03}} In May 2018, it was announced the [[Orion Classics]] would be revived as a multiplatform distribution label, with 8 to 10 films being released per year.{{cite web|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/mgm-relaunches-orion-classics-as-multiplatform-distribution-label-1113714|title=MGM Relaunches Orion Classics as Multiplatform Distribution Label|website=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|first=Pamela|last=McClintock|date=May 21, 2018|accessdate=May 21, 2018}} ==List of Orion Pictures films== {{main|List of Orion Pictures films}} ===Notable films=== During the 1980s and early 1990s, Orion's output included [[Woody Allen]] films, Hollywood blockbusters such as the first ''[[The Terminator|Terminator]]'' and the ''[[RoboCop]]'' films, comedies such as ''[[Throw Momma from the Train]]'', ''[[Dirty Rotten Scoundrels (film)|Dirty Rotten Scoundrels]]'', ''[[Something Wild (1986 film)|Something Wild]]'', ''[[UHF (film)|UHF]]'', and the ''[[Bill & Ted]]'' films, and Best Picture Academy Award winners ''[[Amadeus (film)|Amadeus]]'', ''[[Platoon (film)|Platoon]]'', ''[[Dances with Wolves]]'', and ''[[The Silence of the Lambs (film)|The Silence of the Lambs]]''.{{cite news|title= MEDIA BUSINESS; Can Ninja Turtle Owner Rescue Orion Pictures?|work= The New York Times|date=1992-04-01|url= https://www.nytimes.com/1992/04/01/business/media-business-can-ninja-turtle-owner-rescue-orion-pictures.html?scp=3&sq=Orion%20Pictures&st=cse|accessdate=2010-08-08 | first=Bernard | last=Weinraub}} Following is a list of the major Academy Awards (Picture, Director, two Screenplay and four Acting awards) for which Orion films were nominated. {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center; ===Highest-grossing films=== {| | {| class="wikitable sortable" |+Highest-grossing films worldwide |- ! Rank!! Title !! Year !! Worldwide gross |- | 1 |''[[Dances with Wolves]]'' | 1990 | $424.2 |- | 2 |''[[The Silence of the Lambs (film)|The Silence of the Lambs]]'' | 1991 | $272.7 |- | 3 |''[[The Addams Family (1991 film)|The Addams Family]]'' | 1991 | $191.5 |- | 4 |''[[First Blood]]'' | 1982 | $125.2 |- | 5 |''[[The Terminator]]'' | 1984 | $78.3 |- | 6 |''[[Throw Momma from the Train]]'' | 1987 | $57.2 |- | 7 |''[[Robocop]]'' | 1987 | $53.4 |- | 8 |''[[Dirty Rotten Scoundrels (film)|Dirty Rotten Scoundrels]]'' | 1988 | $42.5 |- | 9 |''[[Bill & Ted's Excellent Adventure]]'' | 1989 | $40.5 |} |} ===Orion's library today=== Almost all of Orion's post-1982 releases, as well as most of the AIP and Filmways backlogs and all of the television output originally produced and distributed by Orion Television, now bear the MGM name. However, in most cases, the 1980s Orion logo has been retained or added, in the case of the Filmways and AIP libraries. Most ancillary rights to Orion's back catalog from the 1978–1982 joint venture period remain with Warner Bros., including such movies as ''[[10 (film)|10]]'' (1979), ''[[Caddyshack]]'' (1980), ''[[Arthur (1981 film)|Arthur]]'' (1981), ''[[Excalibur (film)|Excalibur]]'' (1981), and ''[[Prince of the City (film)|Prince of the City]]'' (1981). Some post-1982 films originally released by Orion — ''[[Lionheart (1987 film)|Lionheart]]'' (1987), ''[[The Unbearable Lightness of Being (film)|The Unbearable Lightness of Being]]'' (1988), and ''[[Amadeus (film)|Amadeus]]'' (1984) (the latter two being [[Saul Zaentz]] productions) — are currently distributed by Warner Bros. as well. [[HBO]] also owns video distribution rights to ''[[Three Amigos]]'' (1986), which co-produced the film and owns pay-TV rights. However, MGM owns all other rights and the film's copyright.{{citation needed|date=December 2012}} ''[[The Wanderers (1979 film)|The Wanderers]]'' is owned by the film's producers; however, the copyright is held by MGM/Orion. Woody Allen's films ''[[A Midsummer Night's Sex Comedy]]'' (1982) and ''[[Zelig]]'' (1983) are the only Orion films from the original joint venture period now owned by MGM. Orion releases produced by the [[Hemdale Film Corporation]] and [[Barry Spikings|Nelson Entertainment]] are included in MGM's library as well, and are incorporated into the Orion library. MGM via [[PolyGram|Polygram Entertainment]] did not acquire the Hemdale films, (which include ''The Terminator'', ''Hoosiers'', and ''Platoon'') or the Nelson films (including the ''Bill & Ted'' films), until MGM via Polygram Entertainment bought the pre-1996 library of PolyGram Filmed Entertainment, which included both companies' libraries, although the television and digital rights to certain Nelson films are now held by [[Paramount Television]], with television syndication handled on behalf of Paramount Television by [[Trifecta Entertainment & Media]]. Many of the film and television holdings of [[The Samuel Goldwyn Company]] have now also been incorporated into the Orion library (with ownership currently held by MGM), and the copyright on some of this material is held by Orion, except ''[[Flipper (1995 TV series)|The New Adventures of Flipper]]'' now carries the MGM Television Entertainment copyright.{{citation needed|date=December 2012}} MGM still holds distribution rights to the 1980s revival of ''[[The Hollywood Squares|Hollywood Squares]]'' and ''[[High Rollers]]'' the company produced, as well as the remnants of the Heatter-Quigley library that was not erased, including all remaining episodes of the original ''Squares''; they do not own the rights to the format, which is currently owned by [[CBS Television Distribution]], successor-in-interest to King World, who purchased the format rights in 1991 and produced another syndicated revival from 1998 to 2004. Orion distributed the first [[Rambo (film series)|Rambo film]], ''[[First Blood]]'' (1982).{{cite web|last=Maslin|first=Janet|title=First Blood (1982) 'FIRST BLOOD'|date=22 October 1982|publisher=''[[The New York Times]]''|url=https://www.nytimes.com/movie/review?res=9E0DE0DB143BF931A15753C1A964948260|accessdate=24 April 2015}} That film, like the rest of the ''Rambo'' franchise, is now owned by [[StudioCanal]] as a result of purchasing the library of its co-distributor, [[Carolco Pictures]].{{cite web|last=Lambie|first=Ryan|title=The rise and fall of Carolco|date=11 March 2014|url=http://www.denofgeek.us/movies/carolco/233689/the-rise-and-fall-of-carolco|accessdate=24 April 2015}} ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==Further reading== * {{cite book |last1=Medavoy |first1=Mike |last2=Young, |first2=Josh |title=You're Only as Good as Your Next One: 100 Great Films, 100 Good Films, and 100 for Which I Should Be Shot |date=2002 |publisher=[[Atria Books]] |location=[[New York City]]}} ==External links== {{Portal|1970s|1980s|1990s|2010s}} *{{Official website|https://orionpictures.com/}} * {{IMDb
