revision.comment: Robot - Moving category Jewish resistance fighters to [[:Category:Jewish resistance members during the Holocaust]] per [[WP:CFD|CFD]] at [[Wikipedia:Categories for discussion/Log/2018 August 10]].
revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Otto Miskolczy | image = | imagesize = 200px | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1909|01|23}} | birth_place = [[Vinkovci]], [[Austria-Hungary|Austro-Hungarian Empire]], (now [[Croatia]]) | death_date = 1978 (aged 69) | death_place = [[Jerusalem]], [[Israel]] | relations = [[Eugen Miskolczy]]
(brother) | spouse = | children = | nationality = [[Croats|Croat]] | other_names = | alma_mater = [[University of Zagreb]] | occupation = [[Entrepreneur]] | known_for = }} '''Otto Miskolczy''' ({{lang-hr| Oto Miškolci}}: 23 January 1909{{spaced ndash}}1978) was [[Croats|Croatia]]n entrepreneur and [[World War II]] [[Yugoslav Partisans|Partisan]]. Miskolczy was born in [[Vinkovci]] on January 23, 1909 to a notable Croatian [[Jews|Jewish]] family Miskolczy. His brother was [[Eugen Miskolczy]]. In Vinkovci he finished public elementary school and [[Gymnasium (school)|Gymnasium]] in 1927. In 1931 he graduated from the [[Faculty of Economics and Business, University of Zagreb]]. After graduation his father sent him on a one-year specialization in [[Trieste]], hoping that he will lead the family trading company after return. At first Miskolczy worked with his father at the family company, but in 1937 he founded his own company "Oto Miškolci" za trgovinu i proizvodnju zemaljskih proizvoda (''for trade and manufacture of land products''). His mother inherited the family company from his father. During World War II, in order to avoid arrest and deportation, all members of Miskolczy family have escaped to [[Croatian Littoral]] which was then under Fascist Italy. Miskolczy settled in [[Crikvenica]]. But soon [[Italian Fascism|Fascists]] yielded under [[Nazism|Nazis]] pressure, and all Jews were interned in camps on the coast and islands. Miskolczy was imprisoned at the concentration camp Kraljevica. In 1943 Italian fascist closed the camp in Kraljevica and moved all prisoners to the [[Rab concentration camp]]. After the [[Armistice between Italy and Allied armed forces|capitulation of Italy]] and the liberation of the camp, Miskolczy joined the [[Yugoslav Partisans|Partisans]]. There worked as a stenographer and stenotypist. After the war he worked for the [[Socialist Republic of Croatia|SR Croatia]] Government in [[Split, Croatia|Split]], and later at the Ministry of supply in [[Zagreb]]. He soon retired due to the deteriorated health and returned to Vinkovci, where he married and helped his wife Ela in the newly formed company. As a most Croatian Jews, Miskolczy was deeply disappointed with the [[Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia|Yugoslavia]]n government and made [[Aliyah]] to [[Israel]] with his wife and mother Berta. He died in Israel in 1978.{{harvtxt|Jaša Romano|1980|p=443}}{{hr icon}} Josip Šarčević: ''[http://free-vk.t-com.hr/Josip-Sarcevic/gospodarstvenici.htm Poznati učenici i profesori Vinkovačke gimnazije]'': pp. 34, 35: year 2004/2005.{{harvtxt|Tomo Šalić|2002|pp=}} == References == {{Reflist|2}} == Bibliography == {{Refbegin}} * {{cite book|last=Romano|first=Jaša|title=Jevreji Jugoslavije 1941-1945: žrtve genocida i učesnici narodnooslobodilačkog rata|year=1980|publisher=Jevrejski Istorijski Muzej, Saveza jevrejskih opština Jugoslavije|location=Beograd|isbn=|ref=harv}} * {{cite book|last=Šalić|first=Tomo|title=Židovi u Vinkovcima i okolici|year=2002|publisher=Židovska općina Osijek - Kratis|location=Osijek - Zagreb|isbn=953-6742-01-2|ref=harv}} {{Refend}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Miskolczy, Otto}} [[Category:1909 births]] [[Category:1978 deaths]] [[Category:People from Vinkovci]] [[Category:Jewish resistance members during the Holocaust]] [[Category:Croatian Jews]] [[Category:Austro-Hungarian Jews]] [[Category:Croatian Austro-Hungarians]] [[Category:Croatian businesspeople]] [[Category:Yugoslav Partisans members]] [[Category:Croatian people of World War II]] [[Category:Stenographers]]

revision.comment: [[WP:AWB/T|All typo fixes]] on, [[WP:AWB/T|typo(s) fixed]]: Paul’s → Paul's (24)
revision.text:
{{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject Musicians --> | name = Paul David Wilson | image = | image_size = | caption = | background = solo_singer | birth_name = Paul David Wilson | alias = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1952|8|30|df=y}} | birth_place=[[Chicago]], [[Illinois]] | instrument = [[Vocalist]], [[Flute]], [[Piano]] | origin = | genre = [[Pop music|Pop]], [[R&B]], [[Jazz]], [[Classical music|Classical]] | occupation = [[Songwriter]], [[Composer]], [[Arranger]], [[conducting|Conductor]], [[Record producer|Producer]], [[executive (management)|Executive]], [[Flutist]] | years_active = 1973-present | label = [[Motown]], [[Columbia Records|Columbia]], [[Arista Records|Arista]], [[Geffen Records|Geffen]], [[Un-D-Nyable Entertainment]] | Advertising Agency = Leo Burnett Worldwide, Burrell Communications Group, LLC, J.Walter Thompson, Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, Needham Harper Worldwide | Corporation = [[McDonald]], [[Ford]], [[Harpo Productions]], [[Disney-ABC Domestic Television]] | associated_acts = [[Jerry Butler (singer)|Jerry Butler]], [[Marvin Winans]], [[Nikki (singer)|Nikki]], [[Common (rapper)|Common]], [[Dejah Gomez]], [[Entourage (band)|Entourage]] | website = }}
'''Paul David Wilson''' (born August 30, 1952) is a [[songwriter]], [[composer]], [[conducting|conductor]], and music [[Record producer|producer]]. Most of his professional life has been devoted to music, including composing for radio and TV commercials. He became the president of a start-up record label begun by [[Frank Thomas (baseball, born 1968)|Frank Thomas]], who was then the starring player on the [[Chicago White Sox]] baseball team.{{Citation needed|date=July 2009}} Wilson suffered a massive and debilitating [[stroke]] when he was 46 years old. Due to the terribly limiting effects of [[aphasia]], a common but complicated and severe post-stroke condition, he was for a number of years unable to communicate without great difficulty.<ref name=business>{{cite news |first=Mark |last=Brown |url= http://www.suntimes.com/output/sports/hurt01.htm1|title=Risky business for Sox slugger Thomas |work=[[Sun Times]] |publisher=[[Sun-Times Media Group]] |accessdate=March 1, 2001}}</ref> His fight back to full functioning has been a decade-long challenge that, although largely successful, in many ways still continues.{{Citation needed|date=July 2009}}
== Biography ==
=== Early life ===
Paul David Wilson was born in [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]]. He was third son to father, Herbert, a classical tenor vocalist and choir director who taught elementary school and retired after becoming a vice-principal of the school. Paul's mother, Odessa, was a child prodigy who grew to become a concert pianist and choir director. She was accomplished in a variety of music genres, but due to her commitment to God, only performed certain styles of music. Paul's early lessons on piano came from his mother, and he grew up absorbing the [[Classical music|classical]] and [[gospel music]] of the choirs and vocal ensembles his parents directed.
While still of pre-school age, Paul began composing simple songs and by the time he began primary school had learned to musically notate the songs he composed. At age 12, Paul began organizing "street corner" vocal ensembles to perform his songs at parties and selected school functions. At 13, he discovered the flute and it soon became his major instrument. Paul attended James H. [[Bowen High School]] in Chicago. In Paul's fourth year of high school, a friend, Arlene Johnson, persuaded him to run for class president. He was elected Senior Class President of Bowen in 1970.
He remembers the day when he was a still-young teenager and "my mother dragged me to a seminar on how to create [[Advertising|commercial]] [[jingles]]." The presenters were [[Dick Marx]], whose young son would later become a pop music star known as [[Richard Marx]], who was then Chicago's most prominent master of music for Radio and TV commercials, and Dr. Thomas Fabish, the concert master of [[DePaul University]]’s music department. The presentation involved a big band, top-notch singers and a film. Even as he listened, Paul was thinking, "I could do that."
Inspired by Primous Fountain III, a young composer at DePaul University, Paul enrolled and majored in music composition and theory. He studied music composition with Dr. Leon Stein, Dr. Phil Winsor and Darlene Cowles, while taking flute with Philip Seeburg and Joseph Kainz. In 1973, he was one of 20 music students from around the U.S. selected by [[Ron Logan]] of [[Walt Disney Entertainment]] to participate in a professional "work experience." Paul remembers it as one of the major highlights of his college career. He wrote at that time in August 1973:
[[Image:piccolo.png|thumb|left|Paul's playing piccolo at [[Disneyland]] -- circa 1973.]] : {{cquote|This work experience for me came at an extremely timely point in my life as far as my musical growth is concerned. Although I had known what I actually wanted to do before starting the program, it has helped me crystallize my personal goals and ambitions, professionally and avocationally, specifically writing, arranging, and performing music in the popular and jazz idioms.}}
During his study at DePaul, he founded, performed in, and composed for many ensembles and often organized concerts and productions that featured works by him and others. In his senior year, Paul was honored by inclusion in "Who's Who Among Students in American Universities & Colleges"<ref>[http://www.whoswhoamongstudents.com/history.asp Whosewhoamongstudents.com] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090201164827/http://whoswhoamongstudents.com/history.asp |date=2009-02-01 }}</ref> and graduated in 1975 with a B.A. in music composition and theory.
=== Career ===
In May 1974, while a senior at DePaul, he landed part-time employment at "Star Point 7," a music production company founded by Chuck Colbert, a producer/musician with a jazz-rock band, [[American Breed]] ("[[Bend Me, Shape Me]]"). Paul started this "job" as an unpaid go-fer, answering phones and doing basic clerical chores. After two months, Paul was eager for a chance to show what he could contribute and saw the situation as an opportunity. "Chuck and his writing partner had parted ways and he needed someone to help finish a project. I was around and available and had the skills. I had to ask him, what are you waiting for?" Once Paul had called attention to his talents, Colbert began using him as a composer and arranger.
A short time later, in the Summer of 1974, Paul met a young musician who was just completing his military service, Danny Leake. At the time, Danny was a talented songwriter and electric guitar player, but would later become one of America's foremost recording studio engineers and one of Paul's closest and most frequent collaborators.
In the Fall of 1975, Danny played a significant role in Paul's life by introducing him to [[Ian Levine]], a producer and songwriter, who was a celebrated member of the [[Europe]]an black music fan base known as the [[Northern Soul]] scene. In 1975, while working with Ian, Paul composed, arranged and produced for [[Dance music|Dance]], [[R&B]] and Northern Soul recording artists, in the course of which he traveled in the U.S. and England. One of the Levine's artists, [[Evelyn Thomas]], scored a chart hit with her first single, reaching the UK Top 30 in 1976 with the single "Weak Spot," and "which was (co-written and) arrangement by Paul."<ref name=weakspot2>{{cite web|last=Answers.com|title=Evelyn Thomas Biography/"Weak Spot" A song written by Ian Levine and Paul David Wilson|url= http://www.answers.com/topic/evelyn-thomas|work=Answers.com|accessdate=}}</ref><ref name=weakspot3>{{cite web|title=Weak Spot, A song written by Ian Levine and Paul David Wilson |url=http://repertoire.bmi.com/title.asp?blnWriter=True&blnPublisher=True&blnArtist=True&page=1&keyid=1621902&ShowNbr=0&ShowSeqNbr=0&querytype=WorkID |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130118063833/http://repertoire.bmi.com/title.asp?blnWriter=True&blnPublisher=True&blnArtist=True&page=1&keyid=1621902&ShowNbr=0&ShowSeqNbr=0&querytype=WorkID |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2013-01-18 |work=BMI |year=1975 |accessdate=2009 }}</ref><ref name=weakspot4>{{cite web|last=Nigel |title=Remember When 1976/Evelyn Thomas/"Weak Spot"A song written by Ian Levine and Paul David Wilson |url=http://www.yearsofgold.org.uk/1976WEEK8FEB21.htm |work=Nigel’s Golden Days |date=February 1976 |accessdate=2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080821101416/http://www.yearsofgold.org.uk/1976WEEK8FEB21.htm |archivedate=2008-08-21 |df= }}</ref> As the writer, Neil Rushton, wrote in a review which appeared in Black Echoes, "Paul put the incredible zinging, scurrying strings in "Your Magic Put A Spell In Me" <ref name=strings>{{cite news | first=Neil |last=Rushton|title= The Man Who Puts Zing Into Levine’s Strings – Paul Wilson |work=Black Echoes, Northern Soul |publisher=Black Echoes, Ltd. |date=April 3, 1976}}</ref><ref>{{YouTube|DN_XdJEUJt4}}</ref> performed by [L.J Johnson [[Ian Levine]]] for Ian Levine productions and also served as the songwriter and arranger for the "1976 Disco classic, originally sung by [[James Wells (activist)|James Wells]],<ref name=firsttimearound>{{cite news |url= http://martinsbox.tripod.com/id17.htm |first=John |last=Abbey |title=James Wells: first time around|work=Place & Face.|publisher= |date= 1975 }}</ref> called "Baby I'm Still The Same Man."<ref>[http://www.discomusic.com/records-more/8383_0_2_0_C/ Discomusic.com]</ref><ref>[https://archive.is/20120723141916/http://www.blinkx.com/video/angelo-starr-baby-i-m-still-the-same-man/Pq2vTo-Yx47RSp7TiCjulQ Blinkx.com]</ref>
Despite the success and trans-Atlantic travel he was experiencing, Paul still lived at home with his mother and father. One day in early 1976, while diligently making "cold calls" from his parents’ basement in hopes of drumming up some fresh music opportunities, Paul found himself talking to [[Jerry Butler (singer)|Jerry Butler]], a fellow Chicagoan who was already well known in American [[soul music]]. Butler had (with [[Curtis Mayfield]]) been one of the original founding members of [[The Impressions]] and then established a long later career as a celebrated solo artist. That lucky phone call not only gave Paul a chance to meet Butler, but soon led to the opportunity to work with him on a few projects, including three albums "Suite For The Single Girl",<ref name=singlegirl>{{cite news|first=Jerry|last=Butler|url=http://www.discogs.com/Jerry-Butler-Suite-For-The-Single-Girl/release/425713 |authorlink=Jerry Butler (singer) |author2=Paul David Wilson |title="Suite For The Single Girl" Produced by Jerry Butler and Paul David Wilson |work=Jerry Butler |publisher=Motown|date= 1977}}</ref> "It All Comes Out In My Song" (title song) and Thelma (Houston) & Jerry<ref>[https://archive.is/20140707194103/http://www.discogs.com/Thelma-Houston-Jerry-Butler-Thelma-Jerry/release Discogs.com]</ref> for the Motown label. Subsequently, Paul and Butler they produce an album on [[Dee Dee Sharp]]-Gample with Philadelphia International. ''Billboard'' said, "writer/co-producer Paul Wilson’s "Invitation" is a regal, touching trumph that alone would have made for worthwhile album." In 1981 with "Breaking and Entering" / "Easy Money," from Sharp-Gamble's album "Dee Dee", Paul's production spent four weeks at number one on the Hot Dance Music/Club Play chart and Dance Chart Billboard.
=== Burrell Communications Group, LLC === [[Image:Earphones Pic.jpg|thumb|left|Wilson shown here listening intently to a playback he recorded -- circa 1981.]]
After two years of working with Chuck Colbert and learning the myriad business-related details one must to be successful in commercial music production, in 1976, at age 24, Paul founded [[Herschel Commercial, Inc]] ("I just named it Hershel Commercial, Inc. because it rhymed, he notes)<ref name=ebony>{{cite book|title= Jingling All The Way To The Bank, Jingle Paul Wilson |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=mjmnsLBB6OYC&printsec=frontcover&dq=ebony#PPA80,M2|work= [[Ebony Magazine]] |publisher=Johnson Publication. |date=March 1981 |accessdate=2009}}</ref> with Maurice Earl, Arlene Johnson and, later, [[Bruce Montgomery (entertainer)|Bruce Montgomery]]. His first client was Chicago-based [[Burrell Communications Group, LLC]],<ref>[http://www.burrell.com/burrell.html Burrell.com] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090122041202/http://burrell.com/burrell.html |date=2009-01-22 }}</ref> founded by Tom Burrell. Although Anna Morris, the creative director of Burrell, thought Paul might benefit from a little more "seasoning" before going out on his own, he proclaimed with great certainty, "Look, I’m ready!" Now, as impressed with his confidence as with his talents, Morris awarded him a package of several arranging spots to produce for Coca-Cola. The tracks featured Kitty Heywood, a sweet-voiced soul singer who had already performed on a number of albums as well as commercials. Once produced, the spots were enthusiastically received, both at the ad agency and at the client. Paul was soon creating and producing a long list of memorable and award-winning spots for Burrell and many other ad agencies, often working with such established artists as: [[Phyllis Hyman]], [[Lena Horne]], [[Anita Baker]], [[Midnight Star]], [[Walter Jackson (singer)|Walter Jackson]], [[The Dells]], [[Peabo Bryson]], Ada Dyer<ref>[http://www.windowsmedia.com/MediaGuide/Templates/ArtistProfile.aspx?p_id=P%20%20%20%20%204146 Windowsmedia.com]</ref> [[Vickie Winans]], [[Tramaine Hawkins]], [[The Bar-Kays]], [[Valerie Simpson]], [[Jo Armstead|Joshie Jo Armstead]], [[Millie Jackson]] and [[Rufus Thomas]].
Also of note is the score Paul composed for a television film "Happy Birthday, Martin" sung by [[Joshie Jo Armstead]], which is on permanent display at the [[Martin Luther King, Jr. National Historic Site|King Center]] in [[Atlanta]].
=== Leo Burnett Worldwide ===
In 1977, a chance meeting at a barbershop brought Paul to the attention of Don Richards, a young vice-president and account executive at [[Leo Burnett Worldwide]], Chicago's largest and most celebrated advertising agency. Richards had been hired to facilitate Burnett's efforts to identify promising new African American staffers and suppliers, so he was ready to talk business even on a weekend trip to his barber. On hearing the young composer's story, Richards handed him a card, saying, "Call me… next week." Paul made sure he called Richards. That meeting was most fortunate for Paul and for Herschel. It set them on the path to success and helped establish their reputation with even the biggest and best clients, which included such major brand names as [[Kraft Foods|Kraft]], [[Quaker Oats]], [[Campbell Soup Company]], [[United Airlines]], [[Kellogg Company]], [[Coca-Cola]], [[Joseph Schlitz Brewing Company]], [[Anheuser Busch]], [[Busch Entertainment]], [[Disney-ABC Domestic Television]], [[Mars Incorporated]], [[Alberto-Culver]] and [[Oprah Winfrey]]’s [[Harpo Productions]]<ref>{{YouTube|fWwTjo3xngo}}</ref> ([[Oprah Winfrey]]). In 1980, People magazine, they featured an article on Paul. The title was "Lookout. A Guide To The Up And Coming." <ref name=lookout>{{cite news |title= Lookout – A Guide To The Up And Coming, Paul David Wilson |work=[[People (magazine)|People]] |publisher=[[Time Inc.]]|date=1980 }}</ref>
Paul says, "To be successful, you have to be a chameleon. You're paid to do a job, not to be a conscience." <ref name=chameleon>{{cite news |first=William A. |last=Henry III |url= http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,949354-2,00.html |authorlink= |author2=Dematria Martiniez |title=Mirror, Mirror, on the Tube |work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |publisher=[[Time Inc.]] |date=August 17, 1981 |accessdate=2009}}</ref> Paul wrote and composed many memorable TV and Radio music spots during the commercial phase of his career. Some of the many highlights include; "I Wanna Pop, I Wanna [[Shasta (soft drink)|Shasta]]"<ref name="Youtube.com">{{YouTube|OXgsa9j81Ng}}</ref> for [[Shasta (soft drink)|Shasta]] Beverages, "Sweet Talker, Betty Crocker" for [[Betty Crocker]], "Mmm, Ahh, Ohh, Pop ‘N Fresh Dough" for [[Pillsbury Company|Pillsbury]]. "Until 1981, I was known for lavish, heartwarming arrangements," says Wilson, who is a classically trained flutist with degrees in composition and orchestration. "Then I had a hit with "I Wanna Pop! I Wanna [[Shasta (soft drink)|Shasta]]!" and suddenly I was the rock ‘n’ roll guy, the king of the synthesizers."<ref name="TheHotJingleHouses">{{cite news |first=Mary Jo |last=Kaplan |title=The Hot Jingle Houses, "Sing Along With Pitch" - Herschel Commercial, Paul David Wilson |work=[[Advertising Age]], [[Creativity]] |publisher=Crain Communications |date=August 1988 }}</ref> Paul won a prestigious [[CLIO]] award for his arranging work on the [[McDonald's]] commercial "Makin’ Music."
===Calling Me Home, Chicago===
{{Listen |filename=Calling_Me_Home,_Chicago I.ogg |title="Calling Me Home, Chicago" (1985) |description=Paul David Wilson compose "Calling Me Home, Chicago" featuring Lee Montgomery (1985).}}
In 1985, Paul scored a true "crossover hit" when a song he’d created for [[Chicago Convention and Tourism Bureau]] and composed both lyrics and music featuring Lee Montgomery "[[Calling Me Home, Chicago]]," a song written for a $10 million state tourism campaign,<ref name=SongOfChicago>{{cite news |title=Lifeline, Song Of Chicago, "Calling Me Home, Chicago," Songwriter -Paul David Wilson |work=[[USA Today]], Life |publisher=Gannett Co., Inc. |date=December 17, 1985 }}</ref> became so instantly popular that it was released as a single and sold through area record stores.<ref name=song>{{cite news|title=Chicago! My Kind of Song |url= http://www.artistdirect.com/nad/store/artist/album/0,,256503,00.htm |work=Artist Direct |accessdate=2009}}</ref><ref name=callingme>{{cite news|first=Paul David |last=Wilson |url=http://cocatalog.loc.gov/cgi-bin/Pwebrecon.cgi?v1=3&ti=1,3&Search%5FArg=Calling%20Me%20Home%2C%20Chicago&Search%5FCode=TALL&CNT=25&PID=9VqjYLsXhR18WKgPvH0Wgmml2t1A4&SEQ=20090301112358&SID=1 |author2=Paul David Wilson |title=Calling Me Home, Chicago |work=Paul David Wilson |publisher=Padavon Music|accessdate=2009}}</ref> Jan Zechman of Jan Zechman Associates said, "For Chicago Tourism, our advertising agency asked six local composers to create a musical centerpiece for our campaign. We expected the competition to be fierce. It was not. One airing of Paul's musical vision was enough to win him the job, and to help us create one of the most memorable and successful tourism campaigns in Chicago history. I believe in the power of words, but the power of Paul's music, his notes, proved mightier than any pen on this day." That song is widely regarded even today as one of the true "classic" songs of Chicago.
[[Ruth L. Ratny]], the owner of the magazine "Screen" and editor, she wrote, "Among the most memorable for the Illinois Department of Tourism, are the unforgettable "Calling Me Home, Chicago." State tourism director Lynda Simon says isn’t surprised that Wilson was able to write words and that went a long way towards popularizing the agency's first major television campaign. "He’s a very talented and creative person," says Simon, "and he’s a joy to work with." <ref name=BestoftheYear>{{cite news |first=Ruth |last= Ratny |title=Best Of The Year, The Composer - Paul Wilson |work=Screen Magazine |publisher=Screen Magazine |date=December 16, 1985 }}</ref>
===Recording and live performance=== In 1987, because of his desire to re-enter the record business, Paul (with attorney Linda Mensch) discovered and produced a new artist, "[[Nikki (singer)|Nikki]]." Eventually signed to [[Geffen Records]], the debut album entitled "Nikki" was released in the summer of 1989. One song, "Notice Me"<ref>{{YouTube|hjUPhhWUKaw}}</ref> was a hit, reaching #21 on the U.S. Billboard Hot 100 and #11 on Billboard's Adult Contemporary chart,<ref name=noticeme>{{cite news|first=Paul David |last=Wilson |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p13798|pure_url=yes}}| authorlink=Nikki (singer) |author2=Paul David Wilson |title=Notice Me, songwriters - Paul David Wilson/Nikki |work=Nikki [[The Billboard Hot 100]] |publisher=Nielsen Company |year= 1990|accessdate=2009}}</ref> bringing Paul honors from [[Broadcast Music Incorporated|BMI]] as writer and publisher of one of the most performed songs of the year.<ref name=noticemebmi>{{cite news |first=Paul David |last=Wilson |url=http://repertoire.bmi.com/title.asp?blnWriter=True&blnPublisher=True&blnArtist=True&keyID=1089389&ShowNbr=0&ShowSeqNbr=0&querytype=WorkID |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130118080014/http://repertoire.bmi.com/title.asp?blnWriter=True&blnPublisher=True&blnArtist=True&keyID=1089389&ShowNbr=0&ShowSeqNbr=0&querytype=WorkID |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2013-01-18 |authorlink=Nikki (singer) |author2=Paul David Wilson |title=Notice Me, songwriters - Paul David Wilson/Nikki |work=[[Broadcast Music Incorporated|BMI]] |publisher=Broadcast Music, Inc. |year=1990 |accessdate=2009 }}</ref>
In early 1989, Paul was called on by noted choral conductor Nathan Carter to orchestrate Robert Ray's "Gospel Mass" for a joint performance of the [[Morgan State University]] Choir and the [[Detroit Symphony]]. Also in 1989, Paul was appointed conductor/artistic director for a concert series entitled "Classic Black" (Executive Produced by Valarie Norman). The first concert was given at Chicago's [[Symphony Center|Orchestra Hall]] in April 1990.
Paul wrote:
: {{cquote|I’m happy where I’m at, " he says, "but I’m not so happy that I don’t want to go forward. I’m still reaching for other goals. I don’t know, maybe I’ll never be satisfied so long as I know there are new musical mountains to climb.<ref name=ebony/>}}
==== Un-D-Nyable Entertainment, Inc.==== [[Image:Paul & Frank.png|thumb|left|[[Frank Thomas (baseball, born 1968)|Frank Thomas]] and Paul David Wilson put the ink on the deal for Un-D-Nyable Entertainment, February 10, 1997.]]
In 1997, Wilson accepted an offer from Frank Thomas, "The Big Hurt"<ref>[http://biography.jrank.org/pages/2715/Thomas-Frank.html Biography.jrank.org]</ref> the star player and home run hitter of the [[Chicago White Sox]], to serve as President of [[Un-D-Nyable Entertainment]], an [[independent record label]]. Paul agreed to run the label in partnership with Thomas.
: {{cquote| My executive responsibility is to manage the day-to-to operations, hire creative talent, set up business relations with manufacturers and distributors and, above all, to find new and exceptional talent. (Screen, Vol. 19, No. 6, February 10, 1997)}}
Their initial release was a CD single entitled "3-5, The White Sox Got’em Open Up Wide," with Frank Thomas featuring D. Stoy.<ref>[http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m1355/is_/ai_19666520 Findarticles.com]</ref> Paul discovered and signed Dejah Gomez,<ref name="Answers.com">[http://www.answers.com/topic/dejah-1998-album-by-dejah Answers.com]</ref> a precociously talented 14-year-old singer and songwriter, and hired Cleo Powell, who had an established reputation locally for recognizing and nurturing talent, as the label's A&R Director.
In 1998, Wilson hired Jun Mhoon, accomplished both as a musician and an executive at A&M Records, as Executive V.P. General Manager and Maurice White, formerly with Columbia Records, as Promotion Director and Jon Smith, Studio Manager. He also signed Entourage (James "Slique" Adams,<ref>[http://www.wikimusicguide.com/Slique Wikimusicguide.com]</ref> Floyd Massey, Eric Wade and Irone Guyton, a R&B singing group), rapper Ant-Dub and STRONG, an R&B group that was a family of five brothers. He then secured the services of songwriters/producers, Jack & Earl and George Claiborne. He soon formed an alliance with the music distributors, Navarro.
In late 1998, Wilson produced the debut CD for Dejah Gomez ("Dejah")<ref name="Answers.com"/> and Entourage ("The Fall Backs of a Playa")<ref>[http://new.music.yahoo.com/singleVideo/?vid=2150397 New.music.yahoo.com]</ref><ref>[http://new.music.yahoo.com/videos/Entourage/When--2150396;_ylt=AqiE6OVWT8569Eu02ik.D_7esyUv New.music.yahoo.com]</ref> and matching videos for the CD songs and a CD single title "I Can’t Hide" featuring STRONG. In December, a single "When," by Entourage, they charted on Billboard.<ref name=When>{{cite news|url=http://www.billboard.com/charts/1998-12-26/r-b-hip-hop-songs|title=Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Singles Sales, "When," Produced by Frank Thomas and Paul David Wilson |work=Billboard [[The Billboard Hot 100]] |publisher=Nielsen Company |year= 1998|accessdate=2009}}</ref> Soon, both Dejah Gomez and Entourage were starting to "take off," but, in January 1999, just as the action and excitement was building for his young record company, Paul Wilson suffered a stroke.
== Health ==
On January 2, 1999, the stroke left the active and energetic 46-year-old composer, producer and businessman suddenly and seriously disabled ([[X-ray computed tomography|CT]]). The doctors revealed that an ischemic [[Stroke|CVA]] of left MCA with hemorrhagic transformation. Paul was told he’d have to accept lasting and severe restrictions on his ability to verbally communicate, due to the post-stroke condition known as [[Aphasia]].<ref>[http://www.asha.org/public/speech/disorders/Aphasia.htm Asha.org]</ref>
Aphasia is the inability to speak, read, write or understand speech. Wilson was hospitalized at West Suburban Hospital Medical Center in [[Oak Park, Illinois|Oak Park]] and [[Northwestern Memorial Hospital]] in Chicago. Subsequently, he went through rehabilitation at the [[Rehabilitation Institute of Chicago]] and [[Willowbrook State School|Willowbrook]].
Paul wrote:
: {{cquote|In Oak Park Hospital and Northwestern Hospital I stayed for a month or so. Then, six months in the rehabilitation center to learn just the basic things like saying my name again, signing my signature, spelling my name, my address, brushing my teeth, all the little things that I had to learn to do all over again.}}
In need of a restful setting for his recuperation, Paul and his wife, Terry, relocated to [[Maui]] in [[Hawaii]] where they lived for five years. Paul eventually found and studied with Dr. Walter Tokishi, a speech therapist, but the scarcity of expert medical support to help him overcome the limitations imposed by his aphasia was still a drawback of living on Maui. In 2005, he returned to Chicago, where he began an intensive rehabilitation regimen, fiercely determined to resume his musical career.
== Personal life == Paul has six brothers. They are: James Warren (classical/gospel organ, piano), Herbert Liston (Acoustic/electric bass), John Oland (vocalist), Mark Andrew, Steward Franklin (B-3, piano). One brother, Mark, died when he was an infant do to heart complication.
Paul has been married and divorced two times and has one stepchild:
*to married Marilyn Baynes from 1978 to 1982; *to married Terry Moore from 1982 to 2005 with one stepdaughter, Carmen and one grandson.
== Professional Activities & Affiliations == He has been a Chicago Chapter Governor and National Trustee of [[The Recording Academy]] ([[NARAS]]) and active on its Education, Finance, Restructuring and Long Range Planning Committee. In the mid-1990s, he was Chicago Chapter President of The Recording Academy and later served as a trustee of the Winans Academy of Performing Arts.<ref>[http://www.winans.spfs.k12.mi.us/ Winans.spfs.k12.mi.us]</ref>
==Awards== *[[Grammy]] "All Out" The Winans *[[Clio]] US Television/Cinema – Best New Arrangements Of Commercial Themes – McDonald's – "Makin’ Music" *[[Clio]] 10 Awards *[[Broadcast Music Incorporated|BMI]] Awards "Notice Me" - As writer and publisher of one of the most performed songs of the year.<ref name=noticemebmi/> *[[CEBA (award)|CEBA]] "Family Is" - McDonald's *[[CEBA (award)|CEBA]] 8 Awards
== Media == Paul performed with the band "The Nightclub Band" on the film, ''[[A Family Thing]]'' ([[Robert Duvall]], [[James Earl Jones]]) which also featured the song "Family Thing Blues"<ref>[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0116275/soundtrack IMDb.com]</ref> on the soundtrack. A film, "Signs," was used with Paul's music jingle, "I Wanna Pop, I Wanna Shasta."<ref name="Youtube.com"/> His song titled, "Invitation" perform by Ada Dyer,<ref name="invitation">{{cite web |last=Wilson, |first=Paul David |url=http://repertoire.bmi.com/title.asp?blnWriter=True&blnPublisher=True&blnArtist=True&page=1&keyid=730008&ShowNbr=0&ShowSeqNbr=0&querytype=WorkID |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130118063727/http://repertoire.bmi.com/title.asp?blnWriter=True&blnPublisher=True&blnArtist=True&page=1&keyid=730008&ShowNbr=0&ShowSeqNbr=0&querytype=WorkID |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2013-01-18 |title=Invitation |format= |work= |publisher= |date=1978 }}</ref><ref>{{YouTube|Bpe34A5P0b0}}</ref> was "sample" and then used another song entitled "Brown Sugar (fine)",<ref>{{YouTube|W-D4KGYt_jM}}</ref> with the film ''[[Brown Sugar (2002 film)|Brown Sugar]]'', which performed by [[Mos Def]] and produced by [[Kanye West]]. (The film's credits of "Brown Sugar (fine)" was incorrect)<ref name="brownsugar">{{cite web |author1=Paul David Wilson |author2=Kanye West |author3=Dante Smith | url =http://repertoire.bmi.com/TitleSearch.asp?querytype=WorkName&page=1&fromrow=1&torow=25&keyname=Brown%20Sugar%20Fine&blnWriter=True&blnPublisher=True&blnArtist=False&blnAltTitles=False | title = Brown Sugar Fine | format = Film | work =Evergreen Productions | publisher = | accessdate = 2002}}</ref>

{{One source|date=August 2014}} {{editorial|date=August 2014}}
'''Public affairs''' generally refer to the building and development of relations between an organization and politicians, governments and other decision-makers.
The industry has developed over recent years and is normally considered a branch or sub-discipline of [[public relations]] (PR). Given the broad nature of public affairs, what exactly the industry encapsulates remains a point of discussion. While often equated with [[lobbying]], this is usually only a small part of what a public affairs practitioner might do. Other typical functions include research, strategy planning and providing advice.
It is difficult to determine the size of the public affairs industry in the [[United Kingdom]]. Studies suggest the industry is becoming more professionalized, and that it is more widespread than often assumed. The [[Chartered Institute of Public Relations]] (CIPR), which is the UK's professional body for public relations including public affairs, estimates there are around 48,000 people involved in PR, of which 30% are involved in public affairs. This research is limited as it only measures specific job titles and those who declare themselves to be working in PR. There are large numbers of professionals providing public affairs services while working under different job titles across a wide variety of sectors. The job titles of public affairs practitioners may vary, depending on the focus of their role, but may include, "public affairs", "external affairs/relations", "corporate communications", "government/parliamentary affairs" and "policy".
Organizations who make use of public affairs are typically large companies, charities, trade unions, membership organizations and interest groups. They will either have staff working directly for them or employ a firm of public affairs consultants. Very often public affairs staff will work with their non-PR colleagues who are experts in a given field.
== Issues of contention in the industry ==
It has been argued that professional lobbying goes against [[democracy]] as it allows big business to buy power and influence with well funded campaigns giving them an unfair advantage. Steps are being taken in several countries to attempt to increase levels of regulation and transparency in the public affairs industry. Several countries have introduced a mandatory register for lobbyists. The [[European Union]] has been working with a voluntary register since July 2008. Many other governments including the United Kingdom are debating a register of some kind.
In the [[United States]], President [[Barack Obama]] has introduced several measures intended to increase transparency in public affairs. In an attempt to close the "revolving door" of executive-branch officials becoming lobbyists immediately following the expiration of their federal appointments, he issued [[Executive order (United States)|Executive Order]] 13490<ref>{{cite web|title=Executive Order 13490 - Ethics Commitments|url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/the_press_office/ExecutiveOrder-EthicsCommitments|website=www.whitehouse.gov|publisher=Office of the President of the United States|date=January 21, 2009}}</ref> on January 21, 2009, dictating, among other things, a two-year ban on lobbying for former top executive branch officials related to any issue that they worked on during their final year in government employment. He also introduced a ban on verbal communication between lobbyists and the federal agencies tasked with awarding economic recovery funds. These measures have proved controversial and while some argue they are a positive and necessary step, others have deemed the policies as failures due to various loopholes.
== Role of a public affairs practitioner ==
Public affairs practitioners are engaged in a variety of roles. These can include lobbying, monitoring and predicting political, legal, economic and social developments, and providing political intelligence and strategic advice. In addition, public affairs practitioners may undertake media relations work, understanding and relating with the many streams of business, trade and electronic media in seeking publicity for an organization or in responding to media inquiries and issues.
Central to all of these areas is the concept of stakeholder relations. Building relationships and partnerships are key when engaging with policymakers. Consideration should be given to potential partnership with a variety of groups and individuals, usually encompassed in the ubiquitous public affairs term "key stakeholders" which includes community groups, pressure groups, [[nongovernmental organizations]], technical experts and policy and influences from [[think tanks]] and academics.
==See also== * [[Lobbying]] * [[Lobbying in the United States]] * [[Lobbying in the United Kingdom]] * [[Fossil fuels lobby]] * [[Advocacy group]] * [[Pharmaceutical lobby]]

{{good article}} {{Infobox non-profit | name = RTI International | image = [[File:RTI International (logo).png|200px]] | caption = | founder = | type = Nonprofit | tax_id = | registration_id = | founded_date = {{Start date and age|1958}} | headquarters = [[Research Triangle Park, North Carolina]] | location_country = [[United States]] | coordinates = {{coord|35|54|9.95|N|78|51|58.26|W|display=inline,title}} | origins = | key_people = E. Wayne Holden (President/Chief Executive Officer) | area_served = Worldwide | products = | services = | focus = | mission = | method = | revenue = {{USD|831.5}} million (2015)<ref name="annualreport">{{cite|url=http://annualreport.rti.org/at-a-glance/|title=2015 Annual Report|accessdate=October 1, 2015|publisher=RTI International}}</ref> | endowment = | num_volunteers = | num_employees = 4,150 (2015)<ref name="annualreport"/> | num_members = | subsid = | owner = | motto = Improving the human condition by turning knowledge into practice | former name = | homepage = {{URL|//www.rti.org/}} | dissolved = | footnotes = }}
'''RTI International''' (formerly '''Research Triangle Institute''') is a [[nonprofit organization]] headquartered in the [[Research Triangle Park]] in [[North Carolina]] that provides research and technical services. It was founded in 1958 with $500,000 in funding by local businesses and the three North Carolina universities in the [[Research Triangle]] region. RTI started with departments for research in isotopes, operational sciences and statistics. It restructured into four departments in 1971 and later created the Office for International Projects, now called the International Development Group.
RTI later split into eleven departments, including Health Research, Drug Discovery & Development, Education & Training Research, Survey Research, among others. The [[US Agency for International Development]] has come to account for 35 percent of RTI's research revenue. RTI research has covered HIV/AIDS, healthcare, education curriculum and the environment, among others. Forbes magazine ranked RTI International sixth of 250 in its America’s Best Employers list for mid-size companies for 2016.<ref>{{citation|date=March 23, 2016|accessdate=April 20, 2016|url=https://www.forbes.com/best-midsize-employers/list/#tab:rank|title=America's Beset Midsize Employers}}</ref> In 2016, RTI acquired business interests in banking/financial consulting to accompany its profitable RTI-Health Solutions, a unit focused on the pharmaceutical and health technology sectors.
==History== [[File:RTP planning.jpg|thumb|left|Planning of the Research Triangle Park]] In 1954, Romeo Guest, a building contractor,<ref>{{citation|date=December 12–13, 2011|first=Dennis|accessdate=January 9, 2013|last=Leyden|url=http://iu.edu/~spea/audretsch-conference/pdf/link_albert_collective%20Entrepreneurship.pdf|first2=Albert|last2=Link|title=Collective Entrepreneurship: The Strategic Management of Research Triangle Park|publisher=University of North Carolina}}</ref> met with the North Carolina state treasurer, Brandon Hodges, and the president of [[Wachovia]], Robert Hanes, to discuss building a research park in North Carolina to attract new industries to the region.<ref name="three">{{citation|title=The Growth of Research Triangle Park|publisher=Dartmouth and University of North Carolina|first=John|last=Scott|first2=Albert|last2=Link|accessdate=January 9, 2013|url=//www.dartmouth.edu/~jtscott/Papers/00-22.pdf}}</ref><ref name="foo">{{cite news|newspaper=Business North Carolina|title=RTI International thinks it can continue to flourish by using minds over matters|first=Edward|last=Martin|date=November 2012|accessdate=January 6, 2013|url=http://businessnc.com/a-world-of-knowledgecategory/}}</ref> They obtained support for the concept of [[Research Triangle Park]] from state governor [[Luther Hodges]] and the three universities that form the [[research triangle]]: [[University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill]], [[Duke University]] and [[North Carolina State University]].<ref name="three"/> The Research Triangle Institute (now RTI International) was formed as the research park's first tenant in 1958 by the park's founders.<ref name="ls">{{cite news|newspaper=The Christian Science Monitor|title=North Carolina Taps Research Triangle|date=February 12, 1960|accessdate=January 8, 2013|url= https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/csmonitor_historic/access/272246772.html?dids=272246772:272246772&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:AI&date=Feb+12%2C+1960&author=By+Charles+Blankstein+Written+for+The+Christian+Science+Monitor&pub=Christian+Science+Monitor&desc=North+Carolina+Taps+Research+Triangle&pqatl=google|first=Charles|last=Blankstein}}</ref> The following January they announced that $1.425 million had been raised by the Research Triangle Foundation to fund the park and that $500,000 of it had been set aside for RTI.<ref name="nyt">{{cite news|title=Research Institute to be set up near 3 North Carolina Schools|pp=116|newspaper=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1959/01/12/archives/research-institute-to-be-set-up-near-3-north-carolina-schools.html|date=January 12, 1959|accessdate=January 6, 2013}}</ref><ref name="five">{{citation|title=Research Triangle Park: Evolution and Renaissance|url=http://www.rtp.org/sites/default/files/RTP_History_0.pdf|date=June 2006|accessdate=January 9, 2013|first=Rick|last=Weddle|first2=Elizabeth|last2=Rooks|first3=Tina|last3=Valdecanas|work=ASP World Conference|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120611192128/http://rtp.org/sites/default/files/RTP_History_0.pdf|archivedate=June 11, 2012|df=}}</ref>
RTI started with three divisions: Isotope Development, Operational Sciences and Statistics Research.<ref name="ls"/> Its first contract was a $4,500 statistical study of morbidity data from Tennessee.<ref name="foo"/><ref name="book">{{citation|url=//www.rti.org/50years/files/rti50_book.pdf|publisher=Greenwich Publishing Group|work=RTI International|title=Impact on a Changing World|accessdate=January 7, 2013|first=Rus|last=Banham|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130923161952/http://rti.org/50years/files/rti50_book.pdf |archivedate=September 23, 2013|df=}}</ref> In RTI's first year of operation, it had 25 staff and $240,000 in research contracts.<ref name="one">{{cite news|newspaper=Waycross Journal-Herald|date=Jul 25, 1988|accessdate=December 18, 2012|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=81laAAAAIBAJ&sjid=nUwNAAAAIBAJ&pg=6796,3041464&dq=research-triangle-institute&hl=en|title=Research Triangle Institute is Quiet Leader in its Fields|publisher=Associated Press}}</ref> Its early work was focused on statistics, but within a few years expanded into radioisotopes, organic chemistry and polymers. In 1960 the Institute had its first international research contract, for an agricultural census in Nigeria.<ref name="foo"/> RTI won contracts with the [[United States Department of Education|Department of Education]],<ref name="book"/> [[United States Department of Defense|Defense Department]], [[NASA]] and the [[United States Atomic Energy Commission|Atomic Energy Commission]], growing to $3.4 million in contracts in 1964<ref>{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=qpkbAAAAIBAJ&sjid=bVEEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6866,900436&dq=research-triangle-institute&hl=en|title=Research Triangle Institute has Shown Remarkable Growth in Five-Year Period|accessdate=December 18, 2012|newspaper=The Dispatch|date=November 13, 1964}}</ref> and $85 million in 1988.<ref name="one"/>
In 1971, RTI's staff of 430 was reorganized into four research groups: social and economic systems, statistical sciences, environmental sciences and engineering, and chemistry and life sciences. It also created a division for education called the Center for Education Research and Evaluation.<ref name="book"/> Four years later, RTI created the Office for International Programs to manage international projects.<ref name="book"/> RTI provided funding assistance to help found the [[North Carolina School of Science and Mathematics]] in 1980,<ref>{{cite news|title=Science, math school opens with first classes|publisher=Associated Press|date=October 3, 1980}}</ref> and two years later was part of a joint venture to create Microelectronics Center of North Carolina (MCNC), a non-profit whose computer network connected local K-12 schools.<ref name="csm">{{cite news|first=Ruth|last=Walker|title=A research center takes root among pine and possums|newspaper=Christian Science Monitor|date=June 15, 1982|accessdate=January 9, 2013|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/1982/0615/061543.html}}</ref> A Health Solutions division formed in 2000 serves the pharmaceutical, biotechnology and medical device industries.<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=Triangle Business Journal|date=February 20, 2006|accessdate=January 19, 2013|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/triangle/stories/2006/02/20/daily4.html?jst=b_ln_hl|title=RTI International Buys Cary Company}}</ref> In 2015, it formed a subsidiary in New Delhi, India. Among other projects, it was funded to develop a waterless toilet for use in third-world countries.<ref name="Ohnesorge 2015">{{cite web | last=Ohnesorge | first=Lauren K. | title=RTI International opens Indian subsidiary, tackles toilets, cancer | website=Triangle Business Journal | date=February 23, 2015 | url=http://www.bizjournals.com/triangle/blog/techflash/2015/02/rti-international-opens-indian-subsidiary-rtp.html | accessdate=August 13, 2015}}</ref>
==Organization== RTI International is a not-for-profit research organization that also includes commercial for-profit industries in business consulting and pharmaceutical sectors. RTI was initially established by three local universities, but managed independently by a separate board and management team.<ref name="csm"/> RTI's structure consists of members of the corporation, the board of governors and corporate officers. The members of the corporation elect governors, who in turn create the organization's policies. Corporate officers are senior managers that report to the board for their area of responsibility.<ref>{{citation|url=//www.rti.org/page.cfm/Corporate_Governance|title=Corporate Governance|publisher=The Research Triangle Institute|accessdate=January 9, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120606201705/http://rti.org/page.cfm/Corporate_Governance|archivedate=June 6, 2012|df=}}</ref>
RTI has eleven service areas:<ref>{{citation|publisher=Research Triangle Institute|url=//www.rti.org/|accessdate=January 7, 2013|title=Main Page}}</ref> {{columns-list|colwidth=30em| *Health Research *Drug Discovery & Development *Education & Training Research *Survey Research & Services *Statistics Research *International Development *Economics & Social Research *Advanced Technology *Energy Research *Environmental Research Services *Laboratory & Chemistry Services }} [[File:RTI staffing distribution.jpg|thumb|400px|right]] RTI also has a separate business called RTI Health Solutions, which supports biotech, diagnostic and medical device companies.<ref name="overview"/> As of 2012, the organization's largest division managed the social, statistical and environmental sciences services. More than half of RTI's staff have advanced degrees in one of 120 fields and work on approximately 1,200 projects at a time.<ref name="foo"/> RTI has partnerships with the Research Triangle Energy Consortium, the Triangle Global Health Consortium and other universities and research organizations. Many of RTI's staff hold faculty positions at the three universities that form the Research Triangle and participate in cooperative research projects.<ref>{{citation|url=//www.rti.org/page.cfm?obj=9EB95F1E-C540-46AE-9BF2BFCE0DD49746|title=University Collaborations|publisher=RTI International|accessdate=February 22, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130218001442/http://www.rti.org/page.cfm?obj=9EB95F1E-C540-46AE-9BF2BFCE0DD49746|archivedate=February 18, 2013|df=}}</ref>
There are nine US offices and nine international locations in France, the United Kingdom, South America, India and Indonesia, among others, supporting operations in 80 countries.<ref name="annualreport"/> About 60 percent of RTI's staff are headquartered on a 180-acre campus inside the [[Research Triangle Park]].<ref name="one"/><ref name="overview">{{citation|title=RTI International Overview|url=//www.rti.org/brochures/rti_trifold_w.pdf|publisher=RTI International|accessdate=February 22, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121124023732/http://www.rti.org/brochures/rti_trifold_w.pdf |archivedate=November 24, 2012|df=}}</ref> Most of RTI International's funding comes from government research contracts.<ref name="foo"/><ref name="annual">{{citation|url=//www.rti.org/annual_reports/2012/rti_ar_2012.pdf|title=2012 Annual Report|publisher=RTI International|accessdate=February 22, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130917082851/http://rti.org/annual_reports/2012/rti_ar_2012.pdf |archivedate=September 17, 2013|df=}}</ref> In 2012 it authored 627 journal articles. RTI staff are not independent researchers, but are instead compensated for their time as salary in exchange for yielding any scientific interests in external publications and extramural funding. At the time, RTI owned 400 patents.<ref name="annual"/> RTI competes with the three universities that form the research triangle and other research institutes for contracts. It bids on $2 billion in research contracts a year and wins approximately 40 percent of the budget it bids on.<ref name="foo"/> While RTI is technically a non-profit research institute, senior employees are rewarded salary bonuses (4% for senior staff, and 9-15% for managers) based on annual performance and corporate profit. However, employees have no current vested interest or role in corporate governance.
==Projects== [[File:RTI scientists.jpg|thumb|right|Wani (left) and Wall (right) holding a piece of tree bark used to synthesize cancer intervention drugs]]RTI International's research has spanned areas like cancer, pollution, drug abuse and education.<ref name="one"/>
RTI scientists [[Monroe Wall]] and [[Mansukh C. Wani]] synthesized anti-cancer treatments [[camptothecin]] in 1966, from the bark of the [[Camptotheca]] tree, and [[Taxol]] in 1971, from a Pacific yew tree.<ref name="O'Connor">{{cite news|last=O'Connor|first=Anahad|title=Monroe Wall, 85, Discoverer Of Drugs That Fight Cancer|work=The New York Times|page=14|date=July 11, 2002|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2002/07/11/us/monroe-wall-85-discoverer-of-drugs-that-fight-cancer.html|accessdate=February 4, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|newspaper=The Charlotte Observer|date=August 16, 1998|pp=1D|first=Leah|last=Ward|title=Quiet Heroes of War on Cancer}}</ref> These two drugs account for $3 billion a year in sales by pharmaceutical companies.<ref name="foo"/> In 1986, RTI was awarded a $4 million contract with the [[National Cancer Institute]] to conduct an eight-year clinical trial on the effects of an anti-smoking campaign.<ref>{{cite news|publisher=Associated Press|title=Greensboro, Raleigh to take part in anti-smoking study|date=September 26, 1986|accessdate=January 10, 2013|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=wfdUAAAAIBAJ&sjid=0TwNAAAAIBAJ&pg=6130,4402881&dq=research-triangle-institute&hl=en}}</ref> Two years later, RTI began a $4.4 million program to coordinate AIDS drug trials for the [[National Institutes of Health]]. This had grown to $26 million by 1988.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=CO&s_site=charlotte&p_multi=CO&p_theme=realcities&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EB6C34F2D68FACD&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM|newspaper=Charlotte Observer|date=August 15, 1988|pp=6C|title=Research Triangle Institute Coordinates US Tests of Drug Treatments|accessdate=December 18, 2012}}</ref>
RTI scientists helped identify toxic chemicals in the [[Love Canal]] in the 1970s.<ref name="foo"/> In 1978, RTI researched the possibility of improving solar cells for the [[US Department of Energy]]<ref>{{cite news|title=Better Solar Energy Cells in Making|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=NuEbAAAAIBAJ&sjid=klEEAAAAIBAJ&pg=5805,95405&dq=research-triangle-institute&hl=en|date=May 1, 1978|accessdate=January 9, 2013|publisher=Associated Press}}</ref> and [[coal gasification]] for the [[Environmental Protection Agency]] in 1979.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=uAoeAAAAIBAJ&sjid=rlEEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6954,3148936&dq=research-triangle-institute&hl=en|publisher=Associated Press|title=Research Triangle Scientists Work to make coal a Safer Fuel Source|accessdate=December 18, 2012}}</ref> It trained Chinese government employees on using computer models to forecast pollution patterns before the 2007 Olympics in Beijing.<ref>{{cite news|date=June 27, 2007|title=Bad weather day in Beijing as thick haze, pollution blanket city|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/espn/wire?section=oly&id=2918511|accessdate=January 21, 2013|publisher=Associated Press}}</ref>
An RTI survey in 1973, commissioned by the [[Bureau of Narcotics and Dangerous Drugs]], confirmed prior research that found no connection between drug use and violent crime, despite prior perceptions of heroin users as more prone to violence.<ref>{{cite news|title=Study Finds Drug Users Not Adding to Violence|publisher=Associated Press|date=June 28, 1973}}</ref> A 1975 study RTI conducted for the National Institute of Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism found that 28 percent of 13,000 teenagers polled were "problem drinkers," despite their age.<ref>{{cite news|publisher=Associated Press|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=t2RAAAAAIBAJ&sjid=2VIMAAAAIBAJ&pg=5641,1961675&dq=research-triangle-institute&hl=en|accessdate=January 6, 2013|title=Teen Drinking Habits Studied|date=November 21, 1975}}</ref> A 1996 study done by RTI and funded by [[the Pentagon]] found that drug abuse in the military had been reduced by 90 percent since 1980.<ref>{{cite news|publisher=Associated Press|date=August 11, 1996|title=Study: Military Drug Use Down}}</ref>
RTI in 1975 recommended that the [[Bureau of the Mint]] halt expensive production of pennies, and replace half-dollars with a new dollar coin.<ref>{{cite news|publisher=The New York Times News Service|title=The Moneychangers: U.S. Conducting Study|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=DZUzAAAAIBAJ&sjid=QuoFAAAAIBAJ&pg=3712,1207635&dq=research-triangle-institute&hl=en|accessdate=January 6, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|publisher=UPI|date=November 3, 1975|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=zLlPAAAAIBAJ&sjid=VVIDAAAAIBAJ&pg=3696,2762792&dq=research-triangle-institute&hl=en|accessdate=January 8, 2013|title=Future Coins May be Different}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|publisher=Associated Press|date=September 17, 1976|accessdate=January 6, 2013|title=U.S. Urged to Drop Pennies|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=M55RAAAAIBAJ&sjid=hm0DAAAAIBAJ&pg=5058,1801524&dq=research-triangle-institute&hl=en}}</ref> In 2001, RTI scientists created a new thinfilm superlattice material that uses the [[thermoelectric effect]] to cool microprocessors.<ref>{{cite journal | last =Bell | first =Philip | title =Cool new film | journal =Nature | date =October 11, 2001 | url =http://www.nature.com/news/2001/011011/full/news011011-12.html | doi =10.1038/news011011-12 | accessdate =January 21, 2013 }}</ref> A 2009 study by RTI and the [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]] published in ''Health Affairs'' estimated that obesity in the US caused $147 billion in increased medical care costs annually.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.upi.com/Health_News/2009/07/27/Medical-costs-for-obesity-top-147-billion/UPI-27351248712231/|publisher=UPI|date=July 27, 2009|title=Medical costs for obesity top $147 billion|accessdate=January 10, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|newspaper=The New York Times|title=Obese Americans Spend Far More on Health Care|first=Roni|last=Rabin|date=July 27, 2009|accessdate=January 10, 2013|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/07/28/health/policy/28obesity.html}}</ref> RTI also developed a reading skill measurement program, the Early Grade Reading Assessment (EGRA), for the USAID and the World Bank. The EGRA has been used in 70 languages and 50 countries.<ref>{{cite news|publisher=International Reading Association|title=A Primer on Early Reading Education in Sub-Saharan Africa|newspaper=Reading Today Online|first=Michelle|last=Commeyras|url=http://www.reading.org/literacy-daily/ira/post/rty/2012/06/27/A_Primer_on_Early_Reading_Education_in_Sub-Saharan_Africa.aspx|accessdate=January 23, 2013|date=June 27, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150204152614/http://www.reading.org/literacy-daily/ira/post/rty/2012/06/27/A_Primer_on_Early_Reading_Education_in_Sub-Saharan_Africa.aspx|archivedate=February 4, 2015|df=}}</ref>
In the 1980s, RTI created and distributed the [[Architecture Design and Assessment System]], a set of software programs that helped model intricate systems. The ADAS programs were produced until the mid-1990s.<ref>G.A. Frank, D.L. Franke, and W.F. Ingogly, "An Architecture Design and Assessment System,"VLSI Design, Vol. 6, No. 8, Aug. 1985, pp. 30-50</ref>
RTI began working for the US Agency for International Development (USAID) after the conflict between Iraq and the US began in 2003.<ref name="foo"/> USAID work represented 35 percent of RTI's revenue by 2010.<ref name="qts"/> An employee of the contractor Unity Resources Group, hired to protect RTI staff doing USAID work in Iraq, shot and killed two Iraqi women on October 9, 2007.<ref>{{cite news|date=October 11, 2007|first=Robin|last=Stringer|accessdate=January 10, 2013|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=aGodLpJAY190&refer=home|title=UN Urges US to Make Iraq Security Firms Accountable|publisher=Bloomberg}}</ref>
In 2004, Nextreme was spun off of RTI to develop a thermoelectric material for semiconductors commercially.<ref>{{cite news|title=RTI International Spinoff Nextreme Raises $13 Million|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/triangle/stories/2008/08/04/daily18.html|newspaper=Triangle Business Journal|accessdate=January 19, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Nextreme Raises $8 Million to Fund Thermoelectric Technology|url=http://eetimes.com/electronics-news/4051657/Nextreme-raises-8-million-to-fund-thermoelectric-technology|first=Spencer|last=Chin|date=February 8, 2005|accessdate=January 19, 2013}}</ref> RTI acquired a healthcare marketing firm called MasiMax in March 2009.<ref>{{cite news|title=RTI International Buys MasiMax Resources|date=March 17, 2009|accessdate=January 19, 2013|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/washington/stories/2009/03/16/daily26.html|newspaper=Washington Business Journal}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=RTI International Converts MasiMax into Division|newspaper=Triangle Business Journal|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/triangle/stories/2010/01/04/daily9.html|accessdate=January 19, 2013|date=January 4, 2010}}</ref> It also created another semiconductor startup that year called SiXis.<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=Triangle Business Journal|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/triangle/stories/2009/09/28/daily23.html|accessdate=January 19, 2012|date=September 29, 2009|title=RTI International, Intersouth Partners Invest $3M in SiXis}}</ref> In 2011 RTI created the Center for Agricultural and Environmental Biotechnology<ref name="qts">{{cite news|title=RTI Lures Brookhaven Researcher to Build ag Research Unit|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/triangle/print-edition/2011/12/16/rti-lures-brookhaven-researcher-to.html?page=all|first=Amanda|last=Hoyle|newspaper=Triangle Business Journal|accessdate=January 19, 2013}}</ref> and in 2012 it acquired a California-based education research firm, MPR Associates.<ref>{{cite news|title=RTI International Acquiring MPR Associates|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/triangle/news/2012/12/12/rti-international-acquiring-mpr.html|newspaper=Triangle Business Journal|first=Lauren|last=Ohnesorge|accessdate=January 18, 2013|date=December 12, 2012}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==External links== {{portal|Companies}} * {{Official website|//www.rti.org/}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Rti International}} [[Category:Multidisciplinary research institutes]] [[Category:Non-profit organizations based in North Carolina]] [[Category:Research institutes in the United States]] [[Category:Research Triangle]] [[Category:1958 establishments in North Carolina]] [[Category:Life sciences industry]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1958]]
